Description: Prices are expected to revert to their 5-day moving average after deviating significantly.

Description: A short-term price outperformance in one asset of a pair versus the other indicates potential mean reversion.
Strong positive momentum is confirmed by increasing volume; strong negative momentum is confirmed by decreasing volume.
A stock's momentum relative to its industry peers predicts future outperformance or underperformance.
Stocks with low P/E ratios relative to their industry are undervalued and likely to appreciate.
Stocks with low Price-to-Book ratios are undervalued and likely to appreciate.
Stocks with high return on equity and low price-to-book ratios are undervalued and likely to appreciate.
Positive news sentiment scores predict higher future returns.
Increased positive social media sentiment leads to a temporary price increase.
Positive revisions in analyst ratings lead to short-term outperformance.
When the Relative Strength Index (RSI) is below 30, the stock is oversold and likely to rebound.
A bullish MACD crossover predicts a price increase.

Description: Assets where the short-term moving average crosses above the long-term moving average will outperform.
Stocks with high recent momentum tend to experience mean reversion; short when momentum is high and long when it's low.
A recent increase in ROE suggests potential price appreciation; a decrease suggests the opposite.
Bullish divergence between price and RSI suggests potential price increase.
Companies with consistently high revenue growth will outperform.
Expression: Revenue_Growth = (Revenue_t - Revenue_{t-1}) / Revenue_{t-1}; Signal = AVG(Revenue_Growth_{t-4}, Revenue_Growth_{t-3}, Revenue_Growth_{t-2}, Revenue_Growth_{t-1}, Revenue_Growth_t)

Description: Combine low P/B ratio (value) with positive recent price momentum to identify high-potential stocks.
When the 5-day moving average crosses above the 10-day moving average, it indicates a buy signal.

Description: When the Relative Strength Index (RSI) falls below 30, a bounce is likely.
A significant increase in volume accompanying a price peak indicates an imminent price reversal.

Description: A significant price increase accompanied by increasing volume confirms the uptrend.
Expression: IF (Price increase > X%) AND (Volume increase > Y%) THEN Stronger Buy Signal

Description: Stocks with P/E ratios significantly below their industry average will experience positive price appreciation in the next quarter.
A sudden surge in positive news sentiment predicts a short-term price increase.

Description: Stocks experiencing a sudden shift from negative to positive news sentiment exhibit higher returns.

Description: Positive correlation between a stock and its sector predicts higher future returns for the stock.
If the correlation between a stock and the market index drops below 0.5 after being above 0.7, a price reversion is expected.
Expression: IF Correlation(StockPrice, MarketIndex)[t-1] > 0.7 AND Correlation(StockPrice, MarketIndex)[t] < 0.5 THEN Price[t+5] > Price[t]

Description: Prices tend to revert to their 20-day moving average; stronger deviations lead to stronger reversion.
Price reversion to the 50-day moving average is stronger when volume is high.
Stocks with positive returns over the past 252 days are expected to continue their upward trend.
Stocks with high positive media sentiment will outperform in a bull market.
Companies with high and increasing Return on Equity (ROE) tend to outperform.

Assets with higher relative strength over the past 10 days will outperform the benchmark in the next 10 days.
Stocks with increasing 20-day price momentum will continue to outperform.
Assets with higher volume-weighted returns over the past 20 days will outperform in the next 20 days.
Expression: signal = SUM(Price_Change[i] * Volume[i] for i in range(t-20,t)) / SUM(Volume[i] for i in range(t-20,t))

Description: Stocks that recently broke above their 20-day moving average with high volume are likely to continue rising.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Price[t] > MA20[t] and Volume[t] > AvgVolume[20]) else 0

Description: Assets with increasing 5-day rolling correlation with their sector index will outperform in the next 5 days.

Description: Assets whose momentum score deviates significantly from its long-term average will revert to the mean.
The price is expected to revert to its average based on a volatility-adjusted moving average.
Expression: volatility_adjusted_ma = 20-day MA / ATR; signal = (volatility_adjusted_ma - Close) / volatility_adjusted_ma if |signal| > 0.1

Description: The rate of change of relative strength predicts future outperformance.
Combine low P/E ratio with positive price momentum for stronger signals.
The 10-day volatility of an asset is expected to revert to its 30-day average volatility.
A stock's P/E ratio is expected to revert to its industry average P/E ratio after significant deviation.

Description: Trading volume will revert to its average after experiencing unusually high or low periods.

Description: The correlation between two assets is expected to revert to its long-term average correlation after a significant change.

Description: Stocks with strong 30-day positive price momentum tend to see a reduction in returns within the subsequent 10 days.

Description: Short-term interest rates revert to their long-term average after significant deviations.

Description: Stocks experiencing large positive earnings surprises often exhibit price mean reversion.

Stocks with negative investor sentiment (e.g., low short interest) combined with low P/E ratios will generate alpha.

Increased volatility in social media sentiment precedes increased price volatility.

A high correlation between daily sentiment and subsequent price changes indicates predictive power.
The impact of positive social media sentiment decays exponentially over time.
High news volume combined with positive news sentiment predicts short-term price increases.
High VIX readings are followed by lower returns as the market stabilizes.
A breakout above or below the recent volatility-adjusted trading range suggests a continuation move.
A pronounced skew in implied volatility suggests future price directional moves.

Negative returns lead to higher future volatility.

Low-volatility value stocks (high P/E ratio) show higher returns during periods of low volatility.

Description: Low volume preceding a significant price move predicts a continuation of the trend.

Description: Assets with unusually wide bid-ask spreads will see a narrowing of the spread and positive price movement.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Exploiting price differences between the closing price of a less liquid market and the opening price of a more liquid market.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity and Volume based Alpha Strategies

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity and Volume based Alpha Strategies

Description: Assets with high turnover ratios relative to their sector will outperform in the short term.

Returns are higher in the last week of the month.

Returns tend to be higher in the days leading up to major holidays.
Stocks that underperform on Fridays tend to outperform on Mondays.

When the relative momentum of a stock pair diverges significantly, a mean reversion is expected.

Description: The price difference between an ETF and its underlying assets will revert to a fair value based on the ETF's holdings and expense ratio within one trading day.
The deviation between an ETF's Net Asset Value (NAV) and its market price will mean-revert.

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Exploiting temporary mispricing between correlated assets
Description: The basis (price difference) between a futures contract and its underlying asset will converge towards zero before expiration.

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Convertible Bonds & Underlying Equity

A temporary breakdown in the cointegration relationship between two assets creates a profitable arbitrage opportunity.

Description: Assets with high 5-day price changes and high volume will exhibit continued momentum.
Assets whose price change accelerates over the last 5 days will continue to outperform.
Assets with high momentum and relatively low P/E ratios will outperform.
Assets with high positive sentiment scores and strong recent price performance will continue to rise.
Stocks with high correlation to strong performing sectors will also see positive momentum.

When volume increases while sentiment remains unchanged or decreases, it predicts a price decline.

When an asset's volume declines while its correlation with the market increases, it suggests potential underperformance.

Description: Stocks with consistently increasing positive sentiment over the past 10 days show stronger future price increases.

Description: Increased positive social media mentions of a stock predict a short-term price increase.

Description: Stock market returns are lower during the summer months (June-August).

Stocks tend to underperform on Mondays.

Description: Returns are higher before major holidays.

Stocks with a significant positive sentiment surge outperform the market in the following 3 days.
Expression: Signal = (Sentiment_t - Sentiment_{t-1})/Sentiment_{t-1}; Buy if Signal > 0.1 and hold for 3 days

Expression: Signal = 1 if (EPS_actual > EPS_estimate) else -1 if (EPS_actual < EPS_estimate) else 0

Description: Positive regulatory news leads to a short-term price jump, decaying over time.
Expression: Signal = 1 if positive regulatory news else 0; Price_prediction = Price_t * (1 + Signal * exp(-decay_rate * time_since_news))

Description: Strong positive sentiment coupled with high volume confirms a bullish trend.

Description: Low P/E ratio stocks with high positive sentiment outperform high P/E ratio stocks with low sentiment.

Description: The impact of news sentiment on returns decays exponentially over time, with a half-life of 3 days.

Stocks with extremely high or low sentiment tend to revert towards the mean in the next week.
A cluster of multiple positive news events for a stock leads to outperformance in the following 5 days.

Description: A sudden increase in positive social media sentiment predicts a short-term price increase.
Expression: signal = (SocialMediaSentiment_t - SocialMediaSentiment_t-1) / SocialMediaSentiment_t-1; if signal > 0.1 then BUY else SELL

Description: High positive sentiment combined with low P/E ratio predicts price appreciation.
Unexpectedly positive sentiment exceeding a threshold predicts a price increase within 2 days.
Expression: IF (NewsSentiment(t) - PredictedSentiment(t) > 0.4) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: Increased volatility in news sentiment predicts increased price volatility.
High correlation between sentiment in related assets suggests a coordinated price movement.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Sentiment_AssetA_t-60:t, Sentiment_AssetB_t-60:t); if Signal > 0.8 then Buy (if positive sentiment in both assets);

Expression: signal = 1 if (price[t] > price[t-1] and volume[t] > 2 * avg(volume[t-20:t-1])) else 0

Expression: Signal = HedgeRatio * Price(StockA) - Price(StockB) ; HedgeRatio = Regression(StockA, StockB)

Description: The z-score of the spread between two highly correlated stocks indicates deviation from the mean.

Value stocks (low P/E, P/B) may outperform in bear markets.
Stocks with high recent returns will continue to outperform.
Positive news sentiment scores correlate with future price increases.
Long positions in high-beta stocks are hedged with short positions in low-beta stocks.
Assets with the highest relative strength over the past 5 days tend to underperform in the subsequent 5 days.
Expression: rs = (Asset_Price_5day_Avg / Benchmark_Price_5day_Avg) ; signal = 1 if rs > 1.1 else -1 if rs < 0.9 else 0

Description: Assets with high volume-weighted relative strength outperform assets with low volume-weighted relative strength.
Expression: vwrs = SUM(Asset_Price_i * Volume_i) / SUM(Benchmark_Price_i * Volume_i) ; signal = vwrs

Description: A breakout above a recent relative strength high signals future outperformance.
Expression: rs_high = MAX(rs_past_20days); signal = 1 if rs_Today > rs_high * 1.02 else 0

Description: Assets with lower P/E ratios relative to their peers tend to outperform in the following period.

Expression: rs = (Asset_Price_15day_Avg / Benchmark_Price_15day_Avg); sentiment = (Bullish_Sentiment - Bearish_Sentiment); signal = rs * sentiment

Description: Assets with low correlation to their benchmark and high relative strength are likely to continue outperforming.

Sub_Hypothesis: Mean Reversion of Relative Strength Rank
Description: Assets with consistently high relative strength rank will eventually see a mean reversion in their rank.
High relative strength stocks with low volatility will generate superior risk-adjusted returns.
Expression: Signal = RS / Volatility; where RS is Relative Strength and Volatility is standard deviation of returns.

Description: The relative strength of one sector versus another will predict outperformance in the stronger sector.
Stocks with significantly positive revenue surprises outperform those with negative or insignificant surprises.
Expression: Signal = (Actual Revenue - Expected Revenue) / Expected Revenue;  Buy if Signal > 0.1

Description: Stocks showing increasing year-over-year earnings growth rates will outperform those with decelerating growth.
Expression: Signal = (Current YoY Earnings Growth - Previous YoY Earnings Growth); Buy if Signal > 0.05

Description: Stocks with upward revisions in earnings estimates outperform those with downward revisions.
Expression: Signal = Number of upward revisions - Number of downward revisions; Buy if Signal > 0

Sub_Hypothesis: High P/E Ratio with Strong Growth
Description: Stocks with high P/E ratios but also exhibiting strong revenue and earnings growth will outperform peers with lower P/E ratios and lower growth.
Expression: Signal = (Revenue Growth * Earnings Growth) / P/E Ratio; Outperformance = 1 if Signal > Median(Signal) else 0

Sub_Hypothesis: Strong Sales Growth and Margin Expansion
Description: Stocks demonstrating both strong sales growth and improving profit margins will outperform those with only one or neither.
Stocks experiencing a significant increase in positive analyst ratings outperform those with declining ratings.
Expression: Signal = (Number of Buy Ratings - Number of Sell Ratings) - Previous Sentiment Score; Buy if Signal > 5

Description: Stocks with low debt-to-equity ratios and high revenue growth will outperform those with high debt and lower growth.
Stocks experiencing a significant increase in institutional ownership will outperform those with declining or stable ownership.
Expression: Signal = (Current Institutional Ownership - Previous Institutional Ownership) / Previous Institutional Ownership; Outperformance = 1 if Signal > Threshold, 0 otherwise

Description: Companies demonstrating strong year-over-year growth in free cash flow will outperform those with weak or declining growth.
Expression: Signal = (Current Year Free Cash Flow - Previous Year Free Cash Flow) / Previous Year Free Cash Flow; Outperformance = 1 if Signal > Threshold, 0 otherwise

Description: High-growth stocks with low correlation to the market index will outperform the market during periods of high market volatility.
Expression: Signal = Growth Rate * (1 - Correlation with Market Index); Outperformance = 1 if Signal > Median(Signal) and Volatility > 15% else 0

Description: Low volatility stocks that have shown positive returns over the past 3 months will continue to outperform.
Expression: signal = sum(returns_t-90:t) if stddev(price_t-90:price_t) < threshold else 0

Description: Stocks with recently decreased volatility relative to their historical volatility will exhibit higher returns than peers with persistent high volatility.
Low volatility stocks with low P/E ratios will outperform higher P/E stocks.
Expression: signal = -1 * P/E_t if stddev(price_t-60:price_t) < threshold else 0

Description: Growth stocks with relatively low historical volatility will outperform in a bull market.
High volatility periods are followed by periods of lower volatility and positive returns.

Sub_Hypothesis: Low Volatility and High Dividend Yield
Description: Low volatility stocks with high dividend yields are expected to outperform their peers due to consistent income stream.
Low volatility stocks within outperforming sectors will outperform higher volatility stocks within the same sectors.
Assets with low correlation to the market tend to outperform in periods of high market volatility.
Expression: Calculate correlation between asset returns and market returns (past year); rank by correlation; long assets with lowest correlations.

Description: Low volatility options strategies can generate alpha due to mispricing in the options market.
Expression: Implement a long straddle/strangle strategy on low volatility assets; adjust position based on implied volatility changes.

Description: Stocks with positive earnings surprises will outperform the market in the following week.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Actual - EPS_Estimate) / EPS_Estimate;  if Signal > 0.1 then BUY else if Signal < -0.1 then SELL else HOLD

Description: Negative surprises followed by a period of low volume may signal a price reversal.
The magnitude of the earnings surprise is positively correlated with subsequent price movement.
Expression: Signal = ABS(Earnings - Expectations); where ABS() is the absolute value of the difference

Description: Positive surprises coupled with high trading volume predict stronger price increases.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * Volume_t; Return = (Price_t+5 - Price_t) / Price_t

Description: Positive surprises lead to higher P/E ratios in the following period, creating a positive signal.
A positive sentiment shift following a positive surprise predicts further price gains.
Expression: Signal = (Sentiment_t+1 - Sentiment_t) * IF(EPS_Reported > EPS_Expected, 1, 0); Return = (Price_t+7 - Price_t) / Price_t

Description: Positive surprises exceeding analyst revisions lead to greater price appreciation.
Expression: Signal = MAX(0, EPS_Reported - Analyst_Revision); Return = (Price_t+10 - Price_t) / Price_t

Description: The impact of an earnings surprise varies across sectors.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * Sector_Weight; Return = (Price_t+5 - Price_t) / Price_t

Description: The relationship between earnings surprise and price movement is stronger during periods of low market correlation.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * (1 - Market_Correlation); Return = (Price_t+3 - Price_t) / Price_t

Description: Companies that beat earnings expectations and raise guidance will outperform those that only beat expectations.
A significant increase in trading volume predicts a continuation of the price trend in the subsequent period.
A sharp increase in volume followed by a sudden decrease in volume within 24 hours often predicts a price correction.
Stocks with a low P/E ratio experiencing a significant volume spike will outperform the market over the next month.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Volume(t) > 3 * AvgVolume(t-20) and PE(t) < 15 and Price(t+20) > Price(t) * 1.1

Description: A volume spike coinciding with a significant drop in sentiment scores signals potential short-term bearish momentum.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > AVG(Volume[t-20:t]) * 2 AND Sentiment[t] < AVG(Sentiment[t-20:t]) * 0.8) THEN Sell ELSE Hold

Description: When a stock experiences a volume spike and its correlation with the market index increases significantly, it suggests increased market interest and potential price appreciation.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Volume(t) > 3 * AvgVolume(t-20) and Correlation(Stock,Index,t) > Correlation(Stock,Index,t-20)+0.1

Description: A significant increase in volume accompanying a price breakout suggests sustained price movement in the breakout direction.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AVG(Volume[t-20:t-1])) AND (Price[t] > Resistance_Level) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A large volume spike accompanying a significant price gap up indicates potential continued upward momentum.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Volume(t) > 3 * AvgVolume(t-20) and Gap(t) > 0.02 * Price(t-1)

Description: A volume spike alongside an increase in volatility can signal a period of heightened uncertainty and potential price swings.
Expression: Signal = +/-1 (Based on price direction) if Volume(t) > 2 * AvgVolume(t-20) and Volatility(t) > Volatility(t-10)

Description: A volume spike during a period of price consolidation can signal the end of the consolidation and the start of a new trend.
Expression: Signal = +/-1 (Based on subsequent price direction) if Volume(t) > 3 * AvgVolume(t-20) and ATR(t-20) < 0.01 * AvgPrice(t-20)

Description: A sudden surge in news volume about a stock precedes a short-term price reversal.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (NewsVolume_t - AVG(NewsVolume, 10))/STDDEV(NewsVolume, 10); if (Signal > 1) then Sell; else if (Signal < -1) then Buy;

Description: Assets with increasing positive sentiment scores over the last week will outperform in the next week.
Earnings surprises (positive or negative) lead to temporary price movements.
Assets with low P/E ratios and high positive sentiment are undervalued.
Stocks with high P/E ratios and negative sentiment are overvalued and likely to depreciate.
Expression: Signal = P/E * Sentiment; if (Signal > 10) then SELL;

Description: Alignment of news sentiment and market sentiment predicts stronger price movements.
Expression: Signal = ABS(Market_Sentiment - News_Sentiment); if (Signal < 0.2) then BUY_IF_Positive_Sentiment else SELL_IF_Negative_Sentiment;

Description: Unexpected positive news coupled with a positive shift in sentiment leads to significant price increases.
Expression: signal = (news_surprise > 0) && (delta(sentiment_score) > 0); if (signal) then buy; else hold;

Description: A break below the neckline of a head and shoulders pattern predicts a price decline.
Expression: IF (Price[t] < Neckline AND PatternDetected('HeadAndShoulders')) THEN signal = -1 ELSE signal = 0

Description: A double bottom pattern followed by a price increase and volume surge predicts continued price appreciation.
Expression: IF (doubleBottomPatternDetected() == TRUE) AND (price[t] > price[t-1]) AND (volume[t] > avg(volume[t-10:t-1])) THEN signal = 1 ELSE signal = 0

Description: Stocks with an RSI below 30 will experience a price rebound in the following week.
A price breakout from a period of low volatility (Bollinger Band squeeze) indicates a strong momentum move.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Price[t] > Upper_Bollinger_Band[t] OR Price[t] < Lower_Bollinger_Band[t] else 0

Description: A break above the upper trendline of a flag pattern indicates a continuation of the prior uptrend.
Expression: IF (Price[t] > UpperTrendline AND PatternDetected('Flag')) THEN signal = 1 ELSE signal = 0

Description: Increased volume during a period of sustained price support suggests a potential price reversal to the upside.
Expression: IF (Price[t] >= SupportLevel) AND (Volume[t] > AVG(Volume[t-10:t-1]) * 1.5) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A significant volume spike accompanied by a price gap suggests continuation of the trend.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Volume[0] > 2 * Avg(Volume, 50) and Abs(Price[0] - Price[-1]) > 0.02 * Price[-1]

Description: Companies with consistently increasing earnings per share (EPS) over the past five years will outperform.
Companies with consistently high return on equity will outperform.
Companies with low standard deviation of earnings per share (EPS) over the past five years will outperform.
Expression: stddev(EPS(t-5), EPS(t-4), EPS(t-3), EPS(t-2), EPS(t-1)) < threshold

Description: Companies with a high current ratio (current assets/current liabilities) will outperform.
Companies with consistently positive free cash flow will outperform.
Expression: FreeCashFlow_t > 0 & avg(FreeCashFlow_t-4, FreeCashFlow_t-3, FreeCashFlow_t-2, FreeCashFlow_t-1, FreeCashFlow_t) > 0

Description: Companies with consistently high profit margins will outperform.
Companies with low employee turnover will outperform.
Companies with a consistently high dividend payout ratio will outperform (within a reasonable range).
Companies with consistently positive sales growth will outperform.
Stocks with positive earnings surprises will exhibit a stronger price rebound in the following three days than those with negative surprises.
Stocks with highly negative post-earnings sentiment will experience a price increase in the week following the announcement.
Expression: Signal = -SentimentScore(post-earnings); if Signal > 0.7 then BUY, else SELL

Description: A large volume spike followed by increased volume the next day predicts further price movement in the same direction.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND Volume[t+1] > Volume[t]) THEN Signal = Sign(Price[t] - Price[t-1]); Buy if Signal = 1, Sell if Signal = -1.

Description: Following earnings announcements, significant one-day price changes will revert partially within the next five days.
Expression: Signal = -1 * Price Change (announcement day); Buy if |Signal| > 5% and Avg(Volume (last 5 days)) > 1M shares

Description: Stocks that miss earnings expectations will continue to decline for at least one trading day.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (EPS < Expected EPS); 0 otherwise; Buy if Signal = 1 && Price < previous day's price

Description: Positive correlation between news sentiment and price change immediately after the announcement indicates higher future returns.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(News_Sentiment_Score, Price_Change) (calculated over first 3 days after announcement)

Description: High volatility following an earnings announcement decays rapidly, creating a short-term trading opportunity.
The magnitude of P/E ratio change after an earnings surprise predicts short-term price movement.
Positive upgrades by multiple analysts after an earnings announcement will lead to increased price performance.
Expression: Signal = Number of analyst upgrades post-earnings; Buy if Signal > 3 and rating increase >1

Description: The magnitude and direction of earnings surprises predict short-term price movements.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS; Buy if Signal > 0.1 and Sell if Signal < -0.1

Description: When a stock is cross-listed on two exchanges, buy on the exchange with the lower price and simultaneously sell on the exchange with the higher price.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The futures price will converge to the spot price as the contract expiration approaches.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Differences between the price of a bond and its corresponding futures contract create arbitrage opportunities.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Profit from discrepancies between spot and forward currency exchange rates by buying a currency forward when the forward rate offers an above-average return relative to interest rate differentials.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Identify instances where an index fund's price deviates significantly from the weighted average of its component stocks and trade accordingly.
