Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The difference between the offered price in a merger and the current market price will converge.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price difference between a stock's price before and after a dividend payment will reflect the dividend amount.
Expression: signal = pre_dividend_price - (post_dividend_price + dividend_amount); if abs(signal) > threshold then exploit pricing discrepancy

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Two highly correlated stocks' spread will revert to its historical mean.
Currencies with higher interest rates will outperform those with lower rates over the next month.
The carry trade is more profitable when the volatility of the high-yield currency is low relative to the low-yield currency.
Announcements of central bank interventions supporting the high-yield currency predict positive returns.
Low correlation between the high-yield currency and a global risk asset (e.g., VIX) improves carry trade performance.
Higher trading volume in the high-yield currency market predicts better carry trade performance.
Deviations from covered interest parity predict short-term gains in the carry trade.
Positive surprises in macroeconomic data for the high-yield country predict better carry trade performance.
Narrower credit spreads in the high-yield country indicate lower risk and potentially better carry trade performance.
Positive sentiment towards the high-yield currency improves carry trade returns.
Low P/E ratio stocks with rising prices in a bull market outperform.
Technology stocks outperform in bull markets.
Expression: Signal =  Weighting of Technology sector stocks in portfolio

Description: Stocks with a sudden increase in positive news sentiment outperform in the short term.
Small-cap stocks will outperform large-cap stocks in a bull market.
Positive earnings surprises lead to higher stock prices.
Low volatility stocks that break above their 20-day moving average will outperform in the following month.
Expression: signal = 1 if price_t > MA(price, 20) and stddev(price_t-20:price_t) < threshold else 0

Description: Growth stocks (high PEG ratio) will outperform value stocks (low PEG ratio) in bull markets.
Stocks showing an increasing correlation with the overall market will outperform.

Group_Hypothesis: Assets with low valuations (relative to fundamentals) tend to generate higher returns
Description: Stocks that have experienced significant price declines relative to their fundamentals will outperform.
Expression: Signal = (Fundamental Value Estimate / Current Market Price) -1

Description: Short-term overbought conditions lead to price reversals in bull markets.
Defensive sectors (e.g., consumer staples) will outperform in bear markets.
Low-volatility stocks will show reduced losses compared to high-volatility stocks in bear markets.
Stocks with high dividend yield will outperform in a bear market.
Stocks with overwhelmingly negative sentiment scores (e.g., from news analysis) will outperform expectations.
Stocks with high profitability and low debt will have better downside protection during bear markets.
Value stocks (low P/E, low P/B) will outperform growth stocks.
Stocks exhibiting relative strength against the market during a bear market may indicate a potential rebound.
Stocks showing a declining correlation with the market can provide portfolio diversification.
The magnitude of the price change following an earnings surprise is amplified by trading volume.
A positive shift in news sentiment following a positive earnings surprise reinforces upward price momentum.
The magnitude of post-earnings analyst rating changes predicts subsequent price movement.
Expression: Signal = SUM(abs(AnalystRatingChange_i)) where i iterates through all analysts.

Description: Stocks with high short interest that beat earnings expectations will experience a larger price increase than those with low short interest.
Expression: Signal = (ShortInterestRatio_t0) * Surprise where Surprise > 0 implies a beat.

Description: Stocks with stronger positive correlation to their sector after a positive earnings surprise outperform.
Positive earnings surprises lead to sustained positive 10-day price momentum.
Larger earnings surprises are associated with higher subsequent price volatility.
Expression: Signal = ABS((Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS);  Volatility Proxy =  Standard Deviation of Price Changes over next 5 days;  Short if Signal > 0.15 and Volatility Proxy > 0.2

Description: A significant increase in implied volatility after the earnings announcement indicates larger price movements.
Expression: Signal = (ImpliedVolatility_t1 - ImpliedVolatility_t-1) / ImpliedVolatility_t-1 where t0 is announcement day.

Description: The difference between the volume-weighted average price and the closing price, normalized by volume, predicts price movements in illiquid assets.
A significant increase in trading volume after a period of low volume predicts a continuation of the prevailing price trend in illiquid assets.
Negative sentiment, coupled with low liquidity, precedes a short-term price bounce in illiquid stocks.
A significant deviation of P/E ratio from its historical average in low liquidity stocks predicts mean reversion.
Decreasing correlation between asset classes during high volatility predicts mean reversion in those assets.
Early access to news or financial data can predict price movements before they are widely reflected in the market, particularly in illiquid assets.
High bid-ask spread volatility in illiquid assets indicates potential for short-term price manipulation and profit.
Stocks with larger positive earnings surprises outperform stocks with smaller or negative surprises in the following week.
Stocks with positive earnings surprises and low pre-announcement volatility outperform those with negative surprises or high volatility.
Stocks exhibiting extreme price changes immediately following the earnings announcement will revert to the pre-announcement mean within three days.
Price is expected to revert towards the volume weighted average price after sharp movements.
Expression: VWAP = SUM(Price * Volume) / SUM(Volume); signal = (Price - VWAP) / VWAP

Description: Stocks with strong positive guidance experience a sustained positive price drift.
Positive surprises in revenue guidance will have a more significant impact than EPS surprises on the stock's price in the following month.
Stocks with overwhelmingly positive sentiment scores from earnings call transcripts outperform.
Stocks that show strong positive returns in the five days after the earnings announcement continue to outperform.
Stocks with high P/E ratios after a positive earnings surprise show a stronger price reversion to the mean in the following month.
Stocks with significant upward revisions in analyst EPS estimates after earnings outperform those with downward revisions.
Higher 10-day average volatility predicts higher future 10-day average volatility.
High VIX values are followed by lower VIX values, predicting negative returns.
High predicted volatility from a GARCH(1,1) model implies higher future volatility.
Stocks with high implied volatility ranks relative to their historical average will experience a mean reversion in volatility and potentially price.
Expression: Signal = (Implied Volatility Rank - Mean(Implied Volatility Rank, 60 days)) / StdDev(Implied Volatility Rank, 60 days)

Description: High correlation between sentiment and volatility predicts sustained high volatility.
A steepening option skew predicts increased future volatility.
Expression: Signal = Difference between 25 delta put and 25 delta call implied volatility

Description: High volatility stocks with high volatility-adjusted P/E ratios are expected to revert.
High volatility in one asset spills over to negatively affect correlated assets.
Expression: signal = -correlation(asset1_volatility, asset2_price) where asset1 and asset2 are correlated

Description: A short-term negative correlation between two assets, amplified by high trading volume in one asset, signals a profitable long position in the high-volume asset.
A sudden increase in positive sentiment for Asset A, while correlation with Asset B remains negative, indicates a short-term buying opportunity in Asset A.
When the correlation between P/E ratios of two assets deviates significantly from their historical average, it predicts a price correction.
Negative news affecting Asset A weakens its positive correlation with Asset B, suggesting a long position in Asset B.
An unusually high correlation between two assets during a short period (e.g., 1 minute) suggests an arbitrage opportunity.
Expression: signal = correlation(AssetA_Price_1min, AssetB_Price_1min) - average(correlation(AssetA_Price_1min, AssetB_Price_1min, lookback=60))

Description: Divergence in the correlation between a specific asset and its regional and global market benchmarks indicates a short-term pricing inefficiency.
A decay in the volatility-adjusted correlation of a pair of assets suggests a temporary mismatch that will soon correct.
Expression: signal = (volatility_adjusted_correlation(AssetA, AssetB, lookback=10) - volatility_adjusted_correlation(AssetA, AssetB, lookback=30)) / stddev(volatility_adjusted_correlation(AssetA, AssetB, lookback=30))

Description: A decrease in the correlation between two assets accompanied by a decrease in liquidity in one asset predicts a temporary price movement.
Assets that deviate from their long-term correlation with a basket of similar assets will revert to the average correlation over time.
Expression: signal = (correlation(Asset_Price, Basket_Price, lookback=10) - average(correlation(Asset_Price, Basket_Price, lookback=252))) / stddev(correlation(Asset_Price, Basket_Price, lookback=252))

Description: Stocks underperform when inflation unexpectedly exceeds expectations.
Financial stocks outperform when the yield curve steepens.
The immediate market reaction to interest rate hikes can predict future price movements.
Expression: Signal =  PriceChange(immediately after rate hike announcement)

Description: A weakening domestic currency relative to major currencies forecasts changes in export-oriented sectors.
Changes in the Consumer Confidence Index precede shifts in consumer discretionary spending and related stocks.
Unexpected changes in unemployment rates can influence investor sentiment and market prices.
Accelerating GDP growth predicts higher corporate earnings and stock market performance.
Market-implied inflation expectations from inflation-linked bonds predict future inflation and asset price adjustments.
Positive correlation between commodity prices and inflation predicts higher inflation-hedged asset returns.
The economic surprise index, capturing deviations from economic forecasts, predicts market direction.
Assets with unusually high volume relative to their 5-day average will experience a price reversion in the following 5 days.
Expression: Signal = (Avg(Volume(t-5:t-1)) / Volume(t)) - 1;  if Signal > Threshold then Sell; else if Signal < -Threshold then Buy

Description: A strong positive correlation between volume and price changes over the past 5 days, combined with a current volume spike, indicates continued upward momentum.
Expression: IF (CORR(Volume[t-5:t], Price[t-5:t]) > 0.8 AND Volume[t] > AVG(Volume[t-20:t]) * 2) THEN Buy ELSE Hold

Description: High volume days with unusually low volatility predict a subsequent sharp price move.
Expression: signal = Volume_t / Volatility_t where Volatility_t is calculated using standard deviation of price changes

Description: Higher highs in price with lower highs in volume suggests a potential price reversal.
Expression: Signal = IF(Price[t] > Price[t-1] AND Volume[t] < Volume[t-1] AND Price[t-1] > Price[t-2] AND Volume[t-1] > Volume[t-2], -1, 0)

Description: An unexpectedly large volume spike predicts a significant price movement in the near future.
A surge in volume coupled with a sudden improvement in news sentiment indicates a bullish signal.
Expression: Signal = Volume * SentimentScore; //Higher values indicate stronger signal

Description: Stocks with significantly higher relative volume compared to their average volume over the past year show stronger upward momentum.
High volume coupled with a low P/E ratio signals potential undervaluation and price appreciation.
Expression: Signal = Volume(t) / P/E(t) if P/E(t) < Avg(P/E(t-20:t-1)) else 0

Description: Divergence between price and OBV, following a significant volume spike, could predict a price reversal.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (OBV[t] is decreasing while Price[t] is increasing) or (OBV[t] is increasing while Price[t] is decreasing) else 0

Description: When the RSI falls below 30, a subsequent rise indicates a price increase.
Expression: IF (RSI < 30) AND (RSI starts increasing) THEN Buy Signal

Description: Stocks with a stochastic oscillator below 20 will outperform the market over the next 2 days.
Stocks where the 5-day moving average crosses below the 20-day moving average will outperform the market over the next 5 days.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (5-day MA < 20-day MA and 5-day MA > 20-day MA (previous day)) else 0

Description: A sudden increase in price in a heavily shorted low liquidity stock indicates a short covering squeeze.
Expression: Signal = (ShortInterestRatio[t] * (ClosePrice[t] - ClosePrice[t-1])) / Volume[t] if ShortInterestRatio[t] > 2 and ClosePrice[t] > ClosePrice[t-1] else 0

Description: Stocks opening significantly lower than their previous day's close tend to outperform in the short-term.
Stocks whose prices are squeezed within the Bollinger Bands (low volatility) are expected to experience higher volatility and potential reversals in the following day.
Stocks experiencing a recent decrease in Average True Range (ATR) are expected to show increased price volatility and potential for reversal in the following days.
Smaller cap stocks with high trading volume relative to their price show higher future returns.
Stocks with significantly higher than expected positive sentiment scores outperform.
Smaller cap stocks with low beta that recently experienced negative returns tend to outperform.
A decrease in short interest following a positive earnings surprise signals further price appreciation.
Expression: Signal = (Short_Interest[t-1] - Short_Interest[t]) / Short_Interest[t-1] if EPS_Surprise[t] > 0 else 0

Description: Growth stocks with lower correlations to the overall market during periods of high market volatility will outperform the market.
Stocks with low debt-to-equity ratios relative to their industry will show higher returns.
Increased volatility in the days leading up to a major news announcement predicts increased post-announcement volatility.
Expression: Signal = STDDEV(PriceChange, 5) * NewsImportance; //NewsImportance is a weighted score based on the importance of the expected news

Description: A sudden increase in negative sentiment scores surrounding the earnings announcement predicts lower post-announcement returns.
Stocks with significant upward revisions in analyst earnings estimates before the announcement outperform those with downward revisions.
Higher post-earnings announcement trading volume predicts larger subsequent price movements.
A significant change in the P/E ratio after the announcement predicts future returns.
Consistent upward trend in earnings growth over multiple quarters outperforms companies with inconsistent growth.
Upward revisions in future earnings guidance after the announcement predict better future returns.
Stocks with high correlation to their sector's price movement around earnings announcements tend to follow the sector trend.
Stocks that experience a significant price drop in the last 5 days will rebound in a bull market.
Expression: Signal = (Price_t - Price_{t-5}) / Price_{t-5} if (Price_{t-5} - Price_{t-10})/Price_{t-10} < -0.05 else 0

Description: Assets with increasing P/E ratio over the past month will continue to exhibit positive price momentum.
Assets with high positive correlation to a strong momentum benchmark over the past month will continue to outperform.
Assets with RSI below 30 will experience a short-term price rebound.
High volatility (as measured by standard deviation) over 30 days will likely be followed by lower volatility.
Following a significant volume spike after an earnings announcement, the price will revert to the pre-announcement average within 3 days.
Expression: Signal = (Average(Volume(T-5:T-1)) - Volume(T)) / Average(Volume(T-5:T-1)); if Signal > 0.5 then SELL else if Signal < -0.5 then BUY else HOLD

Description: Prices that fall below their 20-day moving average are expected to revert upwards.
Stocks with a Price-to-Book ratio significantly below 1 will generate excess returns.
High dividend yield stocks, relative to their historical averages, will outperform low yield stocks.
The spread between earnings yield and bond yield predicts high-yield stock performance.
Expression: Signal = (EarningsYield - BondYield); Long if Signal > Threshold

Description: Assets that have underperformed significantly relative to a benchmark over a short period will outperform over the long term.
Companies with low Enterprise Value to EBITDA ratios relative to industry averages will outperform.
High dispersion between growth and value stocks signals outperformance for value stocks.
Assets underperform after a large VIX increase, but rebound in the following week.
Expression: Signal = (VIX_t - VIX_{t-1}) / VIX_{t-1} ; if Signal > 0.1 then Buy next week

Description: Stocks experiencing a significant decrease in volatility will generate positive returns.
When the Fear-Greed Index diverges from market volatility, it predicts a reversal.
Expression: Signal =  Correlation(FearGreedIndex, Volatility, 10) ; Sell if Correlation < -0.5

Description: High positive correlation between volume and volatility over a period predicts increased price volatility.
Expression: Signal = CORR(Volume[t-n:t], Volatility[t-n:t]) where n is the lookback period and Volatility could be ATR or Standard Deviation of Price

Description: A high implied volatility relative to realized volatility offers a shorting opportunity.
Assets with unusually high trading volume followed by a price drop are likely to rebound within a short time frame.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (Price[t] - Price[t-1]) * Volume[t] / AverageVolume[t-20]  //Price drop,scaled by volume

Description: Highly liquid assets that exhibit recent positive price momentum will continue to outperform.
Expression: Signal = (Price[t] - Price[t-10])/Price[t-10] * Volume[t] / AverageVolume[t-20] //Momentum scaled by liquidity

Description: Stocks with low P/E ratios and high trading volume will generate higher returns than similar stocks with low volume.
A narrowing of the bid-ask spread in an illiquid asset after a period of widening suggests increased liquidity and potential price appreciation.
Expression: Signal = (BidAskSpread_{t-1} - BidAskSpread_t) / BidAskSpread_{t-1} if BidAskSpread_{t-1} > Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: Positive sentiment amplified by high liquidity predicts better returns.
Expression: Signal = SentimentScore[t] * (Volume[t] / AverageVolume[t-30]) //Sentiment multiplied by liquidity ratio

Description: Assets with high liquidity show quicker decay in correlation with the market, offering quicker arbitrage opportunities.
Expression: Signal = -1* (Correlation[t] - Correlation[t-1])*Volume[t]//Negative correlation decay scaled by volume

Description: Assets with high volatility and low liquidity will experience greater future price fluctuations.
Returns are higher before major holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas.
Different sectors exhibit unique seasonal performance patterns.
High positive sentiment coupled with high volume predicts stronger price increases.
Low P/E ratios coupled with improving sentiment suggest potential outperformance.
Expression: signal = (1/pe_ratio[t]) * sentiment_score[t]; // Higher signal indicates better potential

Description: A sudden surge in positive social media mentions predicts short-term price increases.
Expression: Signal = DIFF(Social_Mentions[-1], Social_Mentions[-2]); if Signal > 10000 and Sentiment_Score > 0.8 then BUY; else HOLD;

Description: Positive news sentiment preceding earnings announcements is predictive of positive earnings surprises.
Expression: Signal = AVG(Sentiment_Score[-14:-7]); if Signal > 0.7 and Earnings_Surprise > 0 then BUY; else HOLD;

Description: When news sentiment aligns with positive analyst ratings, it boosts future price performance.
Expression: Signal = Sentiment_Score * Analyst_Rating; if Signal > 1.5 then BUY; else HOLD;

Description: Stocks with high short interest and increasing price will see further price increases due to short covering.
Companies exceeding earnings expectations by a significant margin over the past three months will outperform the market.
Expression: Signal = (Actual_Earnings - Expected_Earnings) / Expected_Earnings;  if Signal > 0.1 then Long else Neutral

Description: Companies experiencing an increasing rate of revenue growth will generate higher returns than those with decelerating growth.
Expression: Signal = (Revenue_Growth_Q2 - Revenue_Growth_Q1); if Signal > 0 then Long else Neutral

Sub_Hypothesis: Low P/E Ratio Relative to Growth
Description: Companies with low P/E ratios relative to their revenue growth rate will outperform the market.
Expression: Signal = Revenue_Growth / P/E; if Signal > Threshold then Long else Neutral

Description: Stocks experiencing an increase in the number of positive analyst revisions will outperform stocks with negative revisions.
Expression: Signal = (#PositiveRevisions - #NegativeRevisions); Buy stocks with high positive Signal

Description: High-growth companies with low betas (low market correlation) will outperform high-growth companies with high betas.
Expression: Signal = Growth_Rate / Beta; if Signal > Threshold then Long else Neutral

Description: Companies with high free cash flow relative to market cap will outperform.
High-growth companies will outperform when investor sentiment favors growth stocks over value stocks.
Expression: Signal = Growth_Sector_Index / Value_Sector_Index; if Signal > Threshold then Long else Neutral

Description: Stocks with significant insider buying activity outperform.
Companies with strong and sustainable competitive advantages will generate higher long-term returns.
Expression: Signal = Qualitative_Assessment_of_Competitive_Advantage; if Signal > Threshold then Long else Neutral

Description: Asset prices are expected to revert after extreme positive or negative sentiment.
Prices touching the upper Bollinger Band (2 standard deviations above the 50-day MA) often revert downwards.
Expression: if Close[t] > Upper_Bollinger_Band[t] then SELL; else if Close[t] < Lower_Bollinger_Band[t] then BUY;

Description: Asset prices are expected to revert when the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) crosses its signal line.
Stocks with unusually low P/E ratios relative to their historical average will experience positive price reversion.
Stocks with a significant difference between intrinsic value (from DCF) and market price will outperform.
Stocks trading at a price significantly below their book value will generate above-average returns.
Companies with a low Enterprise Value to EBITDA ratio relative to peers will show stronger returns.
Assets that have experienced a sharp recent price decline will rebound.
Undervalued stocks exhibiting recent positive price momentum will continue to outperform.
Negative correlation between VIX and SP500 increases predicts higher returns.
Increased volatility coupled with high volume predicts negative returns.
High volatility in high P/E stocks predicts lower future returns.
High implied volatility in option markets predicts lower future stock returns.
A sharp decrease in trading volume signals a potential price correction.
Expression: Signal = (Avg(Volume, 10) / Avg(Volume, 100)); if Signal < 0.5 then Sell

Description: High volume accompanied by a low price implies increased buying pressure and potential future price appreciation.
Expression: Signal = Volume * (1/Price); if Signal > Avg(Signal,20) then Buy

Description: A consistently rising short-term volume suggests an upward trend.
Expression: Signal = Slope(Volume, 5); if Signal > 0 then Buy

Description: A sustained upward price trend confirmed by increasing volume suggests continued upward momentum.
Expression: Signal = correlation(Price(last 20), Volume(last 20)); if Signal > 0.8 then Buy

Description: An unexpected sharp drop in volume may indicate a lack of interest and potential price decline.
Expression: Signal =  Volume(today) / Volume(yesterday); if Signal < 0.2 then Sell

Description: A sharp negative shift in news sentiment followed by a positive shift within three days predicts a price increase.
A significant increase in positive social media sentiment coupled with high trading volume predicts a short-term price increase.
High volatility in news sentiment predicts a decrease in price, unless accompanied by extremely positive sentiment.
Positive news sentiment exceeding a predetermined P/E ratio threshold suggests an undervalued asset and subsequent price appreciation.
Strong positive correlation between sector sentiment and index movement predicts outperformance.
Above-average sector sentiment coupled with positive asset-specific sentiment predicts outperformance within the sector.
Prices revert to the average price after extreme positive or negative news sentiment.
Positive news sentiment following earnings announcements predicts a positive price reaction, adjusted for earnings surprise.
Stock prices react differently to earnings announcements at different times of the year.
Increased selling pressure in December due to tax loss harvesting.
Increased market volatility is observed in the months leading up to a major election.
Stocks with high dividend yields and low price-to-book ratios will generate excess returns.
When the yield spread between high-yield corporate bonds and government bonds widens, high-yield stocks outperform.
Expression: Signal = 1 / (High-Yield Bond Yield - Government Bond Yield)

Description: Stocks with high sensitivity to short-term interest rate changes outperform when interest rates are low.
Expression: Signal = Beta (Stock Price vs. Short-Term Interest Rate) * (1 / Short-Term Interest Rate)

Description: Stocks with high dividend yields relative to their historical price volatility outperform.
Highly leveraged firms with high yields underperform less leveraged firms with similar yields.
High-yield stocks with positive sentiment will outperform those with negative sentiment.
High-yield stocks with low correlation to the market outperform during market downturns.
Expression: Signal = Dividend Yield / (Correlation with Market Index)  // during market downturn periods

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: ETF vs. Underlying Basket
Description: ETFs trading at a discount to their net asset value (NAV) will revert to parity within 5 days.
Expression: Signal = (ETF_Price / NAV_Price) - 1;  Trade = 1 if Signal < -0.01 else 0

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Trading against assets consistently trading above or below their VWAP, especially in illiquid markets, offers potential alpha.
A negative correlation between price and volume immediately after an announcement suggests a short-term price reversal.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Price(T:T+1), Volume(T:T+1)); if Signal < -0.5 then BUY else if Signal > 0.5 then SELL else HOLD

Description: Extreme contango in futures markets will partially revert towards a normal contango/backwardation state within a month.
Expression: Signal = Futures_Price - Spot_Price; Trade = 1 if Signal > 2*std(Signal) else 0 (for contango reversion)

Description: Significant deviations in the basis (Futures Price - Spot Price) from its historical average will revert.
Expression: Signal = (Futures_Price - Spot_Price) - avg(Futures_Price - Spot_Price, window=60); Trade = 1 if abs(Signal) > 2*std(Signal) else 0

Description: Inconsistencies in exchange rates across three currency pairs create a temporary arbitrage opportunity.
Expression: Signal = (USDJPY / EURUSD) * EURJPY - 1; Trade = 1 if abs(Signal) > 0.001 else 0

Description: The spread between two highly correlated assets will revert to its historical mean.
Expression: Signal = (Asset1_Price - Asset2_Price - Avg(Asset1_Price - Asset2_Price, 30)) / StdDev(Asset1_Price - Asset2_Price, 30)

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Index Futures vs. Underlying Index
Description: Index futures trading at a significant premium or discount to the underlying index will revert.
Expression: Signal = (Index_Futures_Price / Index_Price) - 1; Trade = 1 if abs(Signal) > 0.02 else 0

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Convertible bonds will trade at a price reflecting the implied value of the underlying stock and debt.
Expression: Signal = ConvertibleBondPrice - (StockPrice * ConversionRatio + BondValue); Buy if Signal < -Threshold, Sell if Signal > Threshold

Description: Stocks with positive earnings surprises outperform the market in the days following the announcement.
Expression: Signal = EarningsSurprise ; Buy if Signal > Threshold

Description: A sudden increase in news volume related to a stock predicts a temporary price drop, followed by a rebound.
Expression: signal = -1 * (NewsVolume[t] - AVG(NewsVolume, 30)) //Compare current volume to 30-day average

Description: Stocks with consistently increasing positive news sentiment will see increased price momentum.
Negative news events lead to a temporary price drop, followed by a rebound.
High correlation between positive news and positive sentiment predicts higher returns.
The impact of negative news is reduced if overall market sentiment is positive.
High P/E ratios are less concerning when market sentiment is highly positive.
Positive news within a specific sector will outperform the broader market.
High sentiment volatility predicts higher price volatility and thus higher trading volume.
A sudden spike in social media mentions correlated with increased price volatility predicts a price reversal.
Expression: IF (SocialMediaVolume > 2*Avg(SocialMediaVolume, 10 days) AND Volatility > 2*Avg(Volatility, 10 days)) THEN Sell;

Description: A high positive correlation between daily sentiment and price changes suggests a strong predictive relationship.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(SentimentScore, PriceChange, TimeWindow) ; Buy if Signal > Threshold

Description: A significant divergence between positive news sentiment and negative price movement triggers a mean-reversion buy signal.
Expression: IF (NewsSentiment(t) > 0.6 AND PriceChange(t) < -0.02) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: High positive sentiment coupled with increased trading volume predicts a price surge.
Expression: IF (NewsSentiment(t) > 0.8 AND Volume(t) > 1.5 * AVG(Volume, {t-30, t})) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: Excessively negative sentiment following a period of positive sentiment indicates a potential buying opportunity.
Expression: IF (NewsSentiment(t) < -0.8 AND AVG(NewsSentiment, {t-7, t-1}) > 0.5) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: A change in the trend of news sentiment (from positive to negative or vice versa) predicts a change in price trend.
A sudden, significant increase in trading volume relative to the average over the past 20 days predicts a price increase within the next 5 days.
An unusually low trading volume followed by a surge predicts a price reversal within two trading days.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Volume[t] < 0.5 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) and Volume[t+1] > 2 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) and Price[t+2] > Price[t]), else 0

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Exploiting temporary mispricing between correlated assets
Description: Disproportionate volume changes in one asset relative to its correlated pair can signal a temporary mispricing.
A three-day consecutive increase in volume exceeding a threshold predicts a price increase within the next two days.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Volume[t] > Volume[t-1] > Volume[t-2] and Volume[t] > 1.5 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) and Price[t+2] > Price[t]), else 0

Description: A ratio of current day volume to 5-day average volume exceeding a threshold indicates a potential price move.
A strong positive correlation between trading volume and positive sentiment scores suggests a potential upward price trend.
Expression: Correlation = CORREL(Volume, SentimentScore, 20); Buy if Correlation > 0.7

Description: Increase in volume coupled with a decrease in P/E ratio suggests a potential buying opportunity.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Volume[t] > 1.5 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) and P/E[t] < P/E[t-1]), else 0

Description: The spread between two highly correlated stocks will revert to its historical mean.
Two cointegrated stocks with a diverging spread will eventually converge.
Stocks that have performed well over the past three months will continue to outperform.
Smaller-cap stocks are expected to generate higher returns.
Stocks with an RSI below 30 tend to outperform stocks with an RSI above 70 over the next 3 days.
Assets with increasing relative strength momentum outperform assets with declining relative strength momentum.
Assets with high relative strength and low P/E ratios generate superior returns.
Expression: rs = (Asset_Price_30day_Avg / Benchmark_Price_30day_Avg); PE_ratio = Asset_Price / Asset_Earnings; signal = rs / PE_ratio

Description: High relative strength combined with positive news sentiment suggests continued outperformance.
Assets with high relative strength and low correlation to the benchmark tend to outperform those with high correlation.
Assets whose relative strength deviates significantly from their long-term average tend to revert towards the mean.
Expression: Signal = (RS_LongTermAvg - RS_Current) / RS_LongTermAvg; RS_LongTermAvg = 200 day moving average of RS

Description: Assets in the top 20th percentile of relative strength within their sector will outperform.
Expression: percentile_rank = percentile(RS, all_assets_RS); signal = 1 if percentile_rank > 0.8 else 0

Description: Assets exhibiting recent strong earnings surprises will show continued positive momentum.

Sub_Hypothesis: High P/E Ratio with Increasing Revenue
Description: Stocks with high Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratios but accelerating revenue growth will outperform stocks with low P/E ratios and decelerating revenue growth.
Companies with high sales growth and low debt-to-equity ratios will outperform.
Stocks with a significant increase in positive news sentiment will outperform those with negative sentiment.
High-growth stocks with low historical price volatility will outperform high-growth stocks with high volatility.
Expression: Signal = RevenueGrowthRate / Beta; Outperform = Signal > Threshold

Description: Stocks within a sector experiencing high collective growth will outperform those in sectors with low growth.
Stocks with consistently increasing ROE outperform stocks with stagnating or declining ROE.
Expression: Signal =  Current ROE - Previous Year ROE; Buy if Signal > 0.02

Description: Assets with historically low volatility and high dividend yields will generate excess returns.
Assets with historically low volatility will experience higher returns following periods of increased volatility.
Assets with both low beta and low volatility will generate superior risk-adjusted returns.
Low volatility stocks with high trading volume will experience higher returns compared to their low-volume counterparts.
Low volatility stocks with positive sentiment scores will outperform those with negative sentiment.
A portfolio of low-volatility assets with low pairwise correlations will have higher returns than a portfolio of randomly selected assets.
Expression: signal =  (1 - average_pairwise_correlation) * (average_volatility) ;  // average_volatility is an average of the individual volatilities

Description: Positive earnings surprises lead to increased positive price momentum in the following week.
The impact of earnings surprises decays exponentially over time.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_reported - EPS_expected) * exp(-t/), where  is a decay constant

Description: The magnitude of post-earnings surprise analyst revisions predicts subsequent price movements.
Stocks with high short interest will experience a price surge when short-sellers begin covering their positions.
Positive earnings surprises decrease implied volatility, predicting lower future price swings.
Expression: signal = (ActualEPS - ExpectedEPS) / ExpectedEPS; iv_change = (IV(t) - IV(t+5)) / IV(t)

Description: Stocks experiencing a significant volume spike followed by above-average price increases over the next three days will outperform the market.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (Price[t+3] / Price[t] > 1.02) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A large volume spike followed by a sharp price decrease suggests a short-term reversal opportunity.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 3 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (Price[t+1] < Price[t] - 0.01 * Price[t]) THEN Signal = -1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Volume spikes confirming a breakout above a key resistance level indicate a strong bullish signal.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 1.5 * AvgVolume[t-60]) AND (Price[t] > ResistanceLevel) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Stocks with high volume spikes showing a negative correlation with market movement in the following period underperform.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (Correlation(Price[t:t+5], MarketPrice[t:t+5]) < -0.5) THEN Signal = -1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High volume spikes on stocks with low P/E ratios are indicative of undervalued assets likely to appreciate.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 3 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (PEratio[t] < 15) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Significant volume increases coupled with a sudden positive shift in market sentiment predict future price increases.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2.5 * AvgVolume[t-60]) AND (SentimentScore[t] > SentimentScore[t-10] + 0.1) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Volume spikes following a gap-up opening suggest sustained upward momentum.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (Price[t] > Price[t-1] * 1.02) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High volume spikes followed by price reversion towards the 50-day moving average suggest mean reversion opportunities.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 3 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (abs(Price[t+5] - MA50[t+5]) < abs(Price[t] - MA50[t])) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Volume spikes that coincide with price exceeding the upper Bollinger Band indicate potential overbought conditions.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (Price[t] > UpperBollingerBand[t]) THEN Signal = -1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High volume spikes in low-float stocks signal potential for amplified price swings.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 5 * AvgVolume[t-30]) AND (Float < 10000000) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: When price increases despite negative sentiment, a price reversal is likely.
The magnitude of price change after unexpected news is proportional to the news' surprise level.
High trading volume coupled with negative sentiment predicts further price decline.
A high P/E ratio with negative sentiment suggests an overvalued asset.
Assets with low P/E ratios and positive sentiment are likely to outperform.
A head and shoulders pattern followed by a neckline breakout predicts a price decline.
Expression: IF (Head and Shoulders pattern detected) AND (Neckline breakout confirmed) THEN Sell Signal

Description: A double bottom pattern followed by a breakout above the neckline predicts a price increase.
Expression: IF (Double Bottom pattern detected) AND (Neckline breakout confirmed) THEN Buy Signal

Description: A bearish divergence between price and RSI indicates a potential price reversal.
Expression: IF (Price[t] > Price[t-1] AND RSI[t] < RSI[t-1]) THEN signal = -1 ELSE signal = 0

Description: A rising OBV suggests positive momentum driven by increased buying volume.
A significant volume increase confirms a price trend change.
Expression: Trend = sign(Price[t] - Price[t-N]); IF (Volume[t] > 2 * Avg(Volume[t-20, t-1]) AND Trend == sign(Price[t-1] - Price[t-N-1]) ) THEN Signal = Trend ELSE Signal = 0; Buy if Signal = 1; Sell if Signal = -1

Description: Companies with consistently increasing earnings per share (EPS) over the past five years will outperform.
Expression: Average(EPS_t-4, EPS_t-3, EPS_t-2, EPS_t-1, EPS_t) > Average(EPS_t-9, EPS_t-8, EPS_t-7, EPS_t-6, EPS_t-5)

Description: Companies with less volatile year-over-year EPS growth outperform those with highly volatile growth.
Companies with CEOs who have been in their position for a long time will outperform.
Companies with high free cash flow relative to market cap will outperform.
Companies exhibiting consistent positive free cash flow growth will outperform those with declining or negative free cash flow.
Expression: Signal = Average(Free Cash Flow Growth Year 1, Free Cash Flow Growth Year 2)

Description: Stocks that exceed earnings expectations by a large margin will outperform the market in the following week.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS;  if Signal > 0.1 then BUY else if Signal < -0.1 then SELL else HOLD

Description: The impact of positive news on price diminishes exponentially over time.
Expression: signal = sentiment_score * exp(-time_since_news/decay_constant) ; if (signal > threshold) then long else do nothing

Description: Higher pre-earnings announcement volatility predicts lower post-earnings announcement returns.
Stocks with higher correlation to positive news in their sector outperform those with lower correlation.
A large upward revision in analyst earnings estimates after a positive surprise predicts continued price appreciation.
If short interest is high before an earnings announcement and the price dips after bad news, a short squeeze will create a positive price movement.
Companies that exceed earnings expectations will see their P/E ratio expand more significantly than those that miss.
Expression: Signal = (P/E Ratio(Day 3) - P/E Ratio(Day before Announcement)) / P/E Ratio(Day before Announcement) * (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS

Description: The aggregated sentiment of news articles over three days after earnings predicts subsequent price movement.
Expression: Signal = Average(News_Sentiment, window=3 days) after earnings

Description: Stocks that provide unexpectedly positive guidance outperform those with negative surprises.
Expression: Signal =  (Actual Guidance - Expected Guidance) / Expected Guidance; Buy if Signal > 0.05

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price difference between a cross-listed stock on different exchanges will revert to a narrow band within 5 days.
Expression: Signal = abs(Price_ExchangeA - Price_ExchangeB) - Average(abs(Price_ExchangeA - Price_ExchangeB), window=30)

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The difference between the spot exchange rate and the forward exchange rate will adjust to reflect interest rate differentials.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Put-call parity will hold, and deviations present arbitrage opportunities.
Expression: signal = Call_price - Put_price - Stock_price + PV(Strike_price); if abs(signal) > threshold then execute arbitrage trade

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The basis between a stock and the index futures contract on which it is included should converge within a specific band.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price of a convertible bond will converge to the value of the underlying stock plus the bond's straight value.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The spread between two cointegrated assets will revert to its long-run equilibrium within a defined confidence interval.
Higher interest rate differentials between two currencies predict continued appreciation of the high-yield currency.
Currencies with high implied volatility relative to their carry will experience lower volatility and higher returns.
Divergence in correlation between the high-yield and low-yield currencies suggests a potential carry trade reversal.
Positive economic surprises in the high-yielding currency will enhance carry trade returns.
Higher liquidity in the high-yield currency enhances carry trade profitability.
Positive forecast revisions for short-term interest rates in the high-yield currency favor the carry trade.
A higher ratio of long-term to short-term debt in the high-yield country negatively affects the carry trade.
A significant shift in market sentiment towards the high-yield currency supports the carry trade.
Increased funding costs in the low-yield currency reduce carry trade profitability.
Stocks with high P/E ratios that have recently outperformed the market will continue to outperform.
Expression: Signal = (P/E_t) * (Return_t-n / Market_Return_t-n), where n is a lookback period (e.g., 3 months).

Description: Companies exhibiting strong earnings growth but trading at reasonable valuations relative to peers will outperform.
Low volatility stocks that have underperformed their peers in the last month will outperform in the following month.
Cyclicals and technology sectors will outperform defensives in a strong bull market.
Small-cap stocks will exhibit a higher return than large-cap stocks in bull markets.
Stocks with improving profit margins will outperform.
Stocks with low debt-to-equity ratios will outperform.
Stocks that miss earnings expectations significantly will continue to decline for at least one week after the announcement.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Surprise < -0.10) * (Close_Price_t7 - Close_Price_t0) where Close_Price_t7 is closing price 7 days after the announcement.

Description: Positive correlation between post-announcement analyst revisions and initial price reaction predicts further price movement in the same direction.
Expression: Signal = (Correlation(Analyst_Revisions_t1-t7, Price_Change_t0-t1) > 0.5) * Price_Change_t0-t1 where Analyst_Revisions_t1-t7 is analyst revisions from day 1 to 7 and Price_Change_t0-t1 is price change from day 0 to 1.

Description: High short interest before earnings, followed by a positive surprise, will lead to short covering and price increases.
Expression: Signal = Short Interest Ratio * (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS; Buy if Signal > 0.2

Description: The market underreacts to positive earnings surprises in the long term (e.g., 3 months), resulting in continued outperformance.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Surprise > 0) * (Close_Price_t90 - Close_Price_t0) where Close_Price_t90 is the closing price 90 days after the announcement.

Description: The magnitude of PEAD varies across sectors, with some sectors showing stronger post-earnings drift than others.
Expression: Signal = Sector_Specific_PEAD_Factor * EPS_Surprise where Sector_Specific_PEAD_Factor is a sector-specific weight based on historical PEAD performance.

Description: Illiquid assets with extremely negative sentiment scores exhibit a higher probability of short-term price increases.
Significant price gaps upwards in illiquid assets during low volume periods are likely to be followed by a price decrease.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (Price_t - Price_(t-1)) if (abs(Price_t - Price_(t-1)) > GapThreshold) & (Volume_t < VolumeThreshold)

Description: Illiquid assets with exceptionally high P/E ratios compared to their sector tend to experience price corrections.
Assets whose correlation with a momentum index has recently broken above a threshold will outperform.
Significant positive news in low liquidity assets can lead to overreaction and subsequent price decline.
A widening bid-ask spread indicates decreased liquidity and increased price volatility, predicting larger future price swings.
Price breakouts above resistance levels on low volume in illiquid assets are often unsustainable.
A divergence between the price action and relative strength in illiquid assets can predict a price reversal.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (RSI[t] - RSI[t-5]) * (ClosePrice[t] - ClosePrice[t-5]) if Volume[t] < AvgVolume[Past_30_Days] * 0.1 else 0

Description: Stocks with larger-than-expected EPS beats outperform in the following week.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS

Description: Stocks exceeding revenue expectations by a significant margin show stronger post-earnings price momentum.
Expression: Signal = (Actual Revenue - Expected Revenue) / Expected Revenue

Description: Stocks reporting positive earnings surprises exhibit a gradual upward price drift over the next month.
Expression: Signal = Average daily return over 20 trading days following announcement for positive surprise stocks

Description: Stocks experiencing unusually high trading volume on the earnings announcement day exhibit higher returns.
A large increase in volatility around the earnings announcement is followed by a mean reversion in volatility.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (Volatility[t] - Average(Volatility[t-60:t-1])) where t is announcement day

Description: Positive sentiment expressed in the earnings call predicts higher stock prices in the following week.
Expression: Signal = Sentiment Score (e.g., from text analysis of earnings call transcript)

Description: A decrease in correlation with the sector after positive earnings surprises signals outperformance in the subsequent month.
Expression: Signal = (Pre-announcement Sector Correlation - Post-announcement Sector Correlation)

Description: High 5-day rolling volatility predicts higher future 5-day rolling volatility.
The GARCH(1,1) model's volatility forecast predicts the persistence of high or low volatility.
High negative sentiment during high volatility predicts continued high volatility.
A decrease in correlation between asset prices during a period of high volatility suggests an increase in future volatility.
High VIX values predict higher future market volatility.
High implied volatility of options predicts continued high implied volatility.
Frequent large price jumps predict higher future volatility.
High volatility in P/E ratios of an asset predicts price volatility.
A sudden increase in trading volume accompanying a decrease in correlation between two assets signals a temporary decoupling that can be exploited.
When positive news about one asset leads to a temporary decrease in correlation with another asset, a contrarian trade is profitable.
When the correlation between the P/E ratios of two assets deviates significantly from its long-term average, a reversion to the mean is expected.
Expression: signal = (corr(PE_AssetA_1day, PE_AssetB_1day) - avg(corr(PE_AssetA, PE_AssetB), 100)) / std(corr(PE_AssetA, PE_AssetB), 100)

Description: Unexpected news affecting one asset temporarily reduces its correlation with another, creating a short-term trading opportunity.
Assets that show a significant negative correlation over 5 days tend to revert back to their long-term average correlation.
Within a specific sector, pairs with high correlation will temporarily show negative correlation during sector-specific negative news.
Following significant macroeconomic news, temporary deviations from normal asset correlations provide short-term trading signals.
A large difference between the correlation of implied volatilities and the correlation of asset prices signals a short-term mean reversion in price correlation.
Increased liquidity in one asset of a highly correlated pair causes a temporary deviation in correlation.
Stocks with high interest rate sensitivity underperform when rates rise.
Sudden changes in the unemployment rate negatively correlate with market volatility.
High consumer confidence predicts increased consumer spending and economic growth.
Positive housing market sentiment predicts increased construction sector performance.
Rapid money supply growth predicts higher inflation and potentially higher equity prices in the short term.
A PMI above 50 indicates expansion and predicts positive returns for cyclical stocks.
A positive correlation between trading volume and positive sentiment signals sustained upward price movement.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Volume(t-n:t), Sentiment(t-n:t)); if Signal > Threshold then Buy

Description: A dramatic volume spike followed by an immediate significant price drop indicates potential short-selling pressure.
Expression: signal = -1 IF (Volume[t] > 3 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1])) AND (Price[t+1] < Price[t] * 0.95); ELSE signal = 0; //Sell signal if volume spike followed by sharp price drop

Description: Price increases without accompanying volume increases signal weakness and potential reversal.
Expression: signal = -1 IF (Price[t] > Price[t-1] AND Volume[t] < Volume[t-1] AND Volume[t] < Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1])); ELSE signal = 0; //Sell signal if price rises without matching volume increase

Sub_Hypothesis: High Volume on Low P/E Stocks
Description: High volume on stocks with low Price-to-Earnings ratios suggests potential undervaluation and price appreciation.
Expression: signal = 1 IF (Volume[t] > 2 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1])) AND (P/E[t] < 15); ELSE signal = 0; //Buy signal if high volume and low P/E

Description: A significant volume increase immediately following positive news suggests a price increase.
Expression: signal = 1 IF (NewsSentiment[t] > 0.5) AND (Volume[t] > 3 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1])); ELSE signal = 0;  //Buy signal if positive news and large volume increase

Description: High volume with a small price increase or decrease indicates potential distribution by large players.
Expression: Signal = -1 if Volume_t > 2 * Average(Volume_{t-20:t-1}) and abs(Price_t - Price_{t-1}) < 0.01 * Price_{t-1}

Description: Stocks with the strongest negative 10-day momentum are expected to have higher returns than stocks with the strongest positive 10-day momentum in the next 2 days.
Stocks with the highest 5-day volume-weighted average price decline will outperform those with the highest 5-day volume-weighted average price increase over the next 2 days.
Expression: Signal = Rank(-SUM(Price * Volume, last 5 days) / SUM(Volume, last 5 days))

Description: Stocks with the lowest relative strength over the past 5 days against their industry will outperform those with the highest relative strength over the next 1 day.
Stocks that are oversold based on a 14-day RSI indicator are likely to experience a price rebound in the following 1 day.
Stocks with the most negative sentiment shifts (e.g., decrease in news mentions) over the past 24 hours are expected to outperform stocks with positive sentiment shifts in the next 24 hours.
Stocks with the lowest recent correlation to the market index will outperform stocks with the highest correlation over the next 1 day.
Stocks with the highest P/E ratio over the past 3 months and that have seen a recent decline will outperform stocks with low P/E ratios and recent gains over the next 2 days.
High volatility stocks that experience a sharp decline tend to show a short-term price reversal.
High volatility periods are often followed by periods of lower volatility and price reversion.
Small-cap stocks with low beta relative to the market tend to outperform during market downturns.
Stocks that beat short-term earnings expectations show higher returns.
Small-cap stocks with low correlation to their industry peers show higher risk-adjusted returns.
Significant insider buying in small-cap stocks is a bullish indicator.
Stocks with a larger-than-expected positive EPS surprise outperform compared to those with smaller or negative surprises.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS

Description: A significant positive shift in news sentiment before earnings predicts outperformance.
Expression: Signal = (Average Sentiment Score (past 3 days) - Average Sentiment Score (past 10 days))

Description: Stocks that open with a significant gap up after a positive earnings surprise outperform those with smaller gaps.
A significant increase in trading volume coupled with a positive price change after earnings signals continued upward momentum.
Positive guidance surprises (upward revisions of future earnings expectations) generate above-average returns.
A decrease in the P/E ratio after a positive earnings surprise suggests undervaluation and potential outperformance.
The weighted average price, weighted by volume, is expected to revert to its 10-day moving average.
Expression: VWAP = SUM(Price * Volume) / SUM(Volume); signal = (10DMA(VWAP) - VWAP) / VWAP

Description: Stocks with positive 5-day price momentum tend to continue their upward trend.
Stocks with positive 20-day price momentum tend to continue their upward trend.
A Bollinger Band squeeze followed by a breakout predicts a strong price move in the breakout direction.
Expression: IF (Bollinger Bands squeeze detected) AND (Breakout occurs) THEN Buy/Sell Signal based on breakout direction

Description: Price exceeding the Average True Range (ATR) suggests a significant price movement.
Stronger 20-day price momentum is more significant when accompanied by high volume.
Positive sentiment scores from news articles surrounding earnings announcements predict higher returns.
Companies with high Return on Equity growth have higher potential for price appreciation.
Stock price is expected to revert to its average price when sentiment score is significantly above its average.
If the correlation between a stock and its sector drops below a threshold, price will revert.
Expression: correlation = corr(StockPrice, SectorIndex); signal = 1 if correlation < 0.8 else 0

Description: Prices are expected to revert towards the middle Bollinger Band after touching the upper or lower bands.
A stock significantly outperforming or underperforming its sector is expected to exhibit mean reversion in relative strength.
Expression: signal = z-score(StockReturn - SectorReturn); long if signal < -1.5, short if signal > 1.5

Description: A bearish MACD crossover is followed by a price drop, then a mean reversion to the moving average.
Expression: signal = 1 if MACD crosses below signal line and Close < 20-day MA else 0

Description: Stocks that have had the highest 5-day price return will continue to outperform in the next 2 days.
Stocks with increasing positive returns over the last three days will show continued outperformance.
Stocks with expanding P/E ratios over the last 5 days tend to exhibit continued short-term price gains.
Stocks within the best performing sector over the past month will outperform the market.

Description: Assets with historically low correlation to the market that experience a sudden increase in price will outperform.
Expression: Correlation(Asset, Market, 60) < 0.2 AND Price_Change_5D > 0.1; Signal = 1 if True, 0 otherwise

Description: Assets opening significantly higher than the previous day's close will outperform in the following day's trading.
Companies trading at a price-to-book ratio substantially lower than their historical average will generate excess returns.
Stocks that have recently underperformed but exhibit strong fundamental value will subsequently outperform.
Companies with low debt-to-equity ratios and increasing earnings will show superior returns.
Companies that miss earnings expectations but subsequently show strong earnings revisions will see price appreciation.
Stocks with high free cash flow yield relative to their market capitalization will outperform.
Companies with high return on equity (ROE) and low P/B ratios will produce above-average returns.
High short interest levels indicate potential for short covering and increased price.
High-volume stocks that have shown strong upward price momentum will continue to outperform in the short term.

Description: Low P/E ratio stocks with high trading volume will outperform their peers over the next quarter.
Stocks with low volatility adjusted for trading volume are expected to generate higher risk-adjusted returns.
High-volume stocks with strongly positive sentiment scores will outperform in the next week.
High-volume stocks with low correlation to the market index will generate excess returns.
High-volume stocks will outperform during periods of broad market advances.
High-volume stocks with high short interest are more likely to experience short squeezes leading to price increases.
High-volume stocks that exceed earnings expectations will outperform in the following week.
A large imbalance between buy and sell orders in illiquid stocks predicts short-term price movement in the direction of the larger order flow.
Stocks with low post-earnings volatility continue their pre-announcement price trend over the next two weeks.
High volatility combined with unusually high volume predicts a price increase.
A high fear index combined with high market volatility predicts a short-term market decline.
Decreased correlation between a stock and the market index during periods of high market volatility signals an outperformance opportunity.
Low volatility within defensive sectors during periods of high market volatility signals buying opportunities.
High short-term implied volatility relative to long-term implied volatility decays faster than expected, offering profit from shorting short-term volatility.
Expression: Signal = Short-term Implied Volatility - Long-term Implied Volatility

Description: High volatility stocks with low P/E ratios will outperform in the following month.
Market returns are higher in the last few days of the month.
Expression: Signal = Average Return of the last 5 trading days of each month

Description: Stock returns are lower during the summer months (June-August).
Expression: Signal = Average(DailyReturn) for June, July, August

Description: Stock prices tend to react strongly to earnings announcements during specific quarters.
The P/E ratio of stocks exhibits seasonal patterns throughout the year.
Market volatility exhibits different patterns across different months.
Different economic sectors perform better in different seasons.
A sudden spike in negative news sentiment predicts increased price volatility in the short term.
Expression: signal = stddev(sentiment_score, 2); buy if signal > 2 * average(signal, 20)

Description: Strong positive news sentiment for a specific asset, exceeding sector sentiment, predicts outperformance.
Expression: signal = (asset_sentiment - sector_sentiment); buy if signal > threshold

Description: A significant change in sentiment triggers a breakout from the recent price range.
Expression: Signal =  (High[t] > MAX(High, 10) || Low[t] < MIN(Low, 10)) * Sentiment[t]; //Triggers on breakout multiplied by current sentiment

Description: A shift from predominantly negative to positive sentiment in a bearish market indicates a potential market bottom.

Expression: Signal = Index Implied Volatility - Average Constituent Implied Volatility

Description: Disproportionate trading volume in one asset relative to its correlated pair signals a potential price adjustment.
A significant difference in P/E ratios between two correlated companies suggests an arbitrage opportunity.
A composite index based on multiple factors predicts profitable arbitrage opportunities.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The tracking error between an index fund and its benchmark index will revert to the mean over a 30 day period.

Asset prices are expected to revert when the Stochastic Oscillator reaches overbought or oversold levels.
High variance ratios are expected to revert to lower levels over time.
Expression: signal = (1/VarianceRatio) -1; if(signal > 0.2) then position sizing = signal

Description: Stocks with positive news sentiment and strong 10-day price momentum will continue their positive performance.
When the 5-day moving average crosses above the 10-day moving average, a buy signal is generated.
Companies trading at a substantial discount to their book value will outperform the market.
Companies with low Enterprise Value to EBITDA multiples relative to their sector will outperform.
Stocks with multiple analyst upgrades in a short period will outperform due to increased market confidence.
Periods of high volatility tend to persist, leading to further positive or negative returns.
Changes in the skew of market volatility predict a reversal in the current market direction.

Group_Hypothesis: Volatility Changes Predict Future Price Movements
Description: A widening gap between implied and realized volatility suggests future price changes.
Low volatility stocks with positive news sentiment will have higher returns than other low volatility stocks.
Low volatility stocks with decreasing correlation to the market index will generate higher risk-adjusted returns.
Changes in sector-specific volatility predict relative outperformance among sectors.
Assets with consistently low volume exhibit higher price volatility, creating short-term trading opportunities.
Expression: signal = volatility_t / avg(V_{t-n:t}); //volatility_t can be standard deviation of returns

Description: A large volume surge followed by a significant volume drop signals a potential price reversal.
Expression: signal = (V_t - V_{t-1}) / V_{t-1}  if V_t > threshold; //check if the volume drop is substantial next day

Description: Widening bid-ask spreads during high volume indicate a liquidity squeeze and potential price distortions.
Expression: signal = spread_t / V_t; // spread_t is the difference between bid and ask price

Description: A sudden, large increase in volume compared to the average over the last month signals an information event impacting price.
High P/E ratios are more susceptible to price drops during periods of low liquidity.
Expression: signal = P/E_t * (1/avg(V_{t-n:t})); //inverse relationship between P/E and liquidity

Description: Large imbalances in the order book, coupled with high volume, can predict short-term price movements.
Extreme fear (low Fear and Greed Index) predicts a price reversal.
A sudden spike in positive social media mentions predicts short-term price increase.
The impact of news sentiment decays exponentially over time.
Expression: Signal = Sentiment_Score_t * exp(-decay_rate * time_since_news); if Signal > threshold then BUY

Description: Positive news sentiment aligned with upward revisions in analyst ratings predicts sustained price appreciation.
Market volatility is increased during election years.
Increased selling pressure occurs in late November and December due to tax-loss harvesting.
Expression: Signal = (Volume in November and December) / (Average Monthly Volume)

Description: Fund managers adjust portfolios to improve their year-end performance reports.
Expression: Signal = (Change in Portfolio Holdings in December) / (Total Portfolio Value)

Description: High dividend yield stocks that have recently experienced positive price momentum tend to continue outperforming.
Stocks with high dividend yields and low historical volatility tend to outperform.
Narrowing credit spreads indicate future outperformance of high-yield bonds.
Expression: Signal = (High-Yield Corporate Bond Spread - Government Bond Yield) - Average(spread, 6 months)

Description: High dividend yield stocks that exceed earnings expectations tend to outperform in the subsequent period.
High-yield stocks with low leverage will outperform those with high leverage.
Positive market sentiment towards the high-yield currency enhances carry trade profitability.
High-yield assets with low correlation to the market will outperform during market downturns.
Expression: Signal = (Dividend Yield) / (Correlation with Market Index); Long if Signal > 0.1 and Market Correlation < 0.5

Description: The difference between long-term and short-term government bond yields predicts future returns in long-term bonds.
Expression: Signal = (Long-Term Gov't Bond Yield - Short-Term Gov't Bond Yield)

Description: When the volatility of the price spread between two correlated assets falls below its historical average, a mean reversion is likely.

Description: The relative performance of an asset within a correlated pair tends to persist for a short period.
A widening spread between two correlated assets, coupled with high trading volume, suggests a temporary mispricing.
A divergence in P/E ratios of two correlated companies indicates a potential mean reversion in their relative prices.
When implied correlation from options on two assets falls below historical averages, it suggests an opportunity for convergence trades.
Using regression analysis on a basket of correlated assets to identify mispriced assets relative to their predicted values.

Description: A composite score based on several factors (spread, correlation, volume) identifies potential arbitrage opportunities.

Description: Stocks with positive earnings surprises, but negative post-announcement sentiment, will exhibit a delayed price appreciation.

Expression: Signal = P/E * (1 - Sentiment); // Lower values indicate stronger signals

Description: Unexpected positive news coupled with high trading volume leads to short-term price gains.
Stocks with positive news sentiment and high correlation to the market outperform during market uptrends.
A significant positive shift in news sentiment surrounding a company in the 24 hours following an earnings announcement predicts positive returns.
Expression: Signal = (Positive News Mentions - Negative News Mentions) at T+24h - (Positive News Mentions - Negative News Mentions) at T; if Signal > Threshold then BUY else SELL

Description: Discrepancies between predicted and actual sentiment scores predict price reversals.
A delay between positive analyst sentiment and positive market sentiment creates a short-term trading opportunity.
High positive sentiment combined with a low P/E ratio indicates a buy signal, and vice-versa.
Expression: Signal = Sentiment * (1 / PE_Ratio); if Signal > Threshold then Buy_Signal = 1 else Sell_Signal = -1

Description: A sudden increase in positive sentiment, following a period of high short interest, indicates a potential short squeeze.
A sudden, large increase in volume without a corresponding price change predicts an imminent price move.
A strong positive correlation between daily volume and price changes over the past week indicates a continuation of the current trend.
Divergence between rising price and falling volume suggests a potential price correction.
Expression: IF (Price[t] > Price[t-1] AND Volume[t] < Volume[t-1]) THEN Signal = -1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High volume combined with positive sentiment predicts a price increase.
High volume accompanied by a low Price-to-Earnings ratio indicates a potential buying opportunity.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Volume[t] > 1.5 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND P/E[t] < Avg(P/E[t-12:t-1])) else 0

Description: Trading volume consistently above the 200-day moving average suggests strong buying pressure.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > MA(Volume, 200)) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Simultaneous spikes in volume and volatility predict a significant price swing.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 3 * StdDev(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND Volatility[t] > 3 * StdDev(Volatility[t-20:t-1])) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A period of unusually low volume preceding a significant price increase suggests a potential breakout.
Expression: IF (Avg(Volume[t-10:t]) < 0.5 * Avg(Volume[t-50:t-10]) AND PriceChange[t+1] > 2%) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: The spread between two highly correlated stocks will revert to its historical mean.
The spread between two stocks, adjusted for volatility, will revert to its mean.
Individual components of an index will temporarily deviate from their fair value based on their weight in the index.
Expression: Signal = (Component Price / Index Level) - Avg((Component Price / Index Level), 60 days)

Description: Relative performance of different sectors will revert to their historical means.
Expression: signal = (sectorReturn - benchmarkReturn - average(sectorReturn - benchmarkReturn, 60)) / stddev(sectorReturn - benchmarkReturn, 60)

Description: Stocks that have experienced the largest 10-day price momentum drop outperform stocks with the largest 10-day price momentum increase over the next 2 days.
Positive news sentiment will correlate with short-term price increases.
Stocks with P/E ratios significantly deviating from their historical average will revert.
Assets with consistently high relative strength over a 20-day period will likely continue to outperform in the next 10 days.

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Exploiting temporary mispricing between correlated assets
Description: A large difference in the P/E ratios of two correlated companies suggests mispricing and potential mean reversion.
Assets in the top percentile of relative strength tend to outperform.
Assets with high relative strength that become oversold (e.g., RSI below 30) may experience a short-term price bounce.
Expression: Signal = 1 if RS_t > 0 and RSI_t < 30, 0 otherwise

Description: An increasing rate of change in relative strength signals a strong uptrend.
Expression: Signal = Delta(RS_t) where Delta is the change in relative strength

Description: Stocks with rapidly increasing P/E ratios will outperform stocks with decreasing or stable P/E ratios.
Expression: Signal = (Current P/E Ratio - Previous P/E Ratio) / Previous P/E Ratio; Outperformance = 1 if Signal > Threshold, 0 otherwise

Description: Stocks with high positive correlation between sales growth and stock price will outperform.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Sales Growth, Stock Price); if Signal > 0.7 then BUY else SELL

Description: Stocks experiencing high trading volume concurrently with positive news announcements will outperform those with low volume.
Expression: Signal = Volume * Positive News Score; Outperform if Signal > Threshold (adjust based on historical data)

Description: Low volatility stocks that have shown positive returns over the past month will continue to outperform in the next month.
Expression: Signal = (Return(Price, 20)[t] / StDev(Price, 20)[t]) if StDev(Price, 20)[t] < Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: Low volatility stocks with low Price-to-Earnings ratios will outperform higher P/E counterparts.
Expression: Signal = 1 / P/E[t] if StDev(Price, 60)[t] < Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: Low volatility stocks with improving sentiment despite negative market sentiment will outperform.
Expression: Signal = SentimentScore[t] - MarketSentiment[t] if StDev(Price, 60)[t] < Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: A sudden increase in trading volume in a low volatility stock signals a potential price increase.
Expression: Signal = Volume[t] / SMA(Volume, 20)[t] if StDev(Price, 20)[t] < Threshold && (Volume[t] / SMA(Volume, 20)[t] > Threshold2); 0 otherwise

Description: Low volatility stocks that break out from their historical correlation with the market are poised for outperformance.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Price, MarketIndex, 60)[t] - SMA(Correlation(Price, MarketIndex, 60), 20)[t] if StDev(Price, 60)[t] < Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: Low volatility stocks with high dividend yields will generate higher risk-adjusted returns.
Expression: Signal = DividendYield[t] if StDev(Price, 60)[t] < Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: Low volatility stocks that exceed earnings expectations will experience a positive price reaction.
Expression: Signal = (EarningsSurprise[t] / StDev(EarningsSurprise, 4)[t]) if StDev(Price, 60)[t] < Threshold && EarningsSurprise[t] > 0 ; 0 otherwise

Description: Low volatility stocks with decreasing short interest are expected to outperform.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (ShortInterest[t] - ShortInterest[t-20]) if StDev(Price, 60)[t] < Threshold; 0 otherwise

Description: Positive earnings surprises lead to sustained price increases over the next 10 trading days.
