Description: Larger earnings surprises are associated with increased post-announcement price volatility.
Expression: Signal = ABS((Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS) * Volatility_t+5

Description: A large positive earnings surprise will lead to a significant increase in trading volume in the following 3 days.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) / EPS_Expected; VolumeSurge = (AVG(Volume[t+1:t+3]) - AVG(Volume[t-21:t])) / AVG(Volume[t-21:t]);

Description: The speed of analyst price target revisions after a surprise predicts subsequent price changes.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) / EPS_Expected; RevisionSpeed = (NewTarget - OldTarget) / TimeToRevision;

Description: The post-earnings announcement drift will be amplified if the stock's sector is also performing strongly.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Stock Return, Sector Return, 10 days) * (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS

Description: Positive earnings surprises lead to increased short covering, resulting in a short-term price spike.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) / EPS_Expected; ShortInterestChange = (ShortInterest[t] - ShortInterest[t+1]) / ShortInterest[t];

Description: The product of the earnings surprise and the stock's beta predicts volatility.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * Beta; Alpha = Correlation(Signal, Volatility_t10)

Description: Strong positive price momentum in the three days following an earnings announcement predicts further upward movement.
Expression: Signal = (Price(T+3) - Price(T)) / Price(T); if Signal > 0.05 then BUY else SELL

Description: A large volume spike accompanying a breakout above a significant resistance level predicts continued upward price movement.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 3 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND Price[t] > ResistanceLevel) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Stocks with high relative strength experiencing a volume spike exhibit stronger price momentum.
Expression: RSI = RSI(Price, 14); IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AvgVolume[t-20]) AND (RSI[t] > 70) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0; Buy if Signal = 1

Description: A price move significantly above the 5-day VWAP after a volume spike predicts a mean reversion towards the VWAP.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND Price[t] > VWAP(5)[t] + 2*StdDev(Price[t-4:t])) THEN Signal = -1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High volume coupled with negative sentiment suggests potential short-covering and a price increase.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Volume[t] > 2*AvgVolume[t-20] and Sentiment[t] < AvgSentiment[t-20]) else 0

Description: A volume spike in undervalued stocks (low P/E ratio) indicates a potential buying opportunity.
Expression: Signal = Volume / PERatio; // Higher values are more bullish

Description: High positive correlation with a market index over the past 5 days suggests continued short-term momentum.
A volume spike accompanying a gap up in price signals continued upward movement.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AVG(Volume[t-10:t]) AND Price[t] > Price[t-1] * 1.02 ) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: A significant volume spike followed by increased 10-day volatility suggests higher risk and potential for large price swings.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND Volatility(10)[t] > 2 * Volatility(10)[t-10]) THEN Signal = 0.5 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Increased volume of negative news correlates with increased short-term price volatility.
Expression: Signal = STDDEV(Price, 1) * SUM(NegativeNewsScore, 5); if (Signal > Threshold) then Sell; else Buy;

Description: A correlation between sentiment and price with a time lag suggests predictive power.
Expression: Correlation(SentimentScore(t-k), Price(t))  //Find optimal k through backtesting

Expression: signal = sentiment * volume; if (signal > threshold) then BUY; else SELL;

Description: Positive sentiment in a sector outperforming the market predicts further outperformance.
Expression: signal = (SectorSentiment - MarketSentiment) / MarketSentiment; if signal > 0.1 then BUY sector stocks

Description: A price consolidation within a flag pattern followed by a breakout confirms the prior trend.
A breakout from a wedge pattern indicates a continuation of the trend.
Expression: IF (WedgePatternDetected(Price[t-n:t]) AND Price[t] > WedgeHigh OR Price[t] < WedgeLow) THEN BUY (if upward break), SELL (if downward break)

Description: A price drop below the VWAP indicates potential for further decline.
Expression: IF Price[t] < VWAP[t] THEN Signal = -1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A rising OBV line that confirms a rising price trend suggests a continuation of the upward momentum.

Description: Increased volatility following an earnings announcement indicates a higher probability of a significant price move in the next 2 days.

Description: Assets with recent negative returns exceeding -2% will outperform in the next day.

Stocks with high recent price momentum will continue to outperform in a bull market.
Undervalued stocks, as measured by low P/E ratios, will outperform in a bull market.

Description: In bull markets, the technology sector outperforms other sectors.
Stocks with positive news sentiment exhibit higher returns during bull markets.

Description: Stocks with historically low volatility will outperform in a bull market.
Stocks with increasing correlation to the market index will outperform.
Low beta stocks will outperform in a bear market.
Stocks in defensive sectors (e.g., consumer staples) will outperform.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Sector in ['Consumer Staples', 'Utilities'] else 0

Description: Stocks with negative sentiment scores underperform.
Stocks that have significantly underperformed their 200-day moving average will revert to the mean.
Low-debt stocks will outperform in a bear market.
High-quality stocks (high return on equity, low leverage) will outperform.
Stocks with decreasing correlation to the market index will outperform.
Undervalued stocks (low P/B, low P/E) may outperform during bear market rebounds.
Stocks exceeding earnings expectations by more than 5% will experience a positive price drift over the next 3 trading days.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) > 1.05 THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0;  Return = Price_t+3 - Price_t

Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) < 0.9 THEN Signal = (Price[t+10] - Price[t]) / (Price[t] - Price[t-1]) ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Stocks exceeding earnings expectations will experience P/E ratio expansion in the following week.

Description: Stocks missing earnings expectations will show increased correlation with their sector in the following days.

Description: Analyst rating upgrades following a positive earnings surprise signal further price increases.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual > EPS_Estimate) AND (Analyst_Rating_Upgrade_t+5 > 0) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Larger-than-expected earnings surprises (positive or negative) lead to higher volatility in the following week.
Expression: IF (ABS(EPS_Actual - EPS_Estimate) / EPS_Estimate > 0.1) THEN Signal = Volatility_t+5 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Extreme price movements immediately following an earnings announcement will partially revert within 5 days.
Assets with consistently low trading volume that experience a small price increase will see further gains.
A price move that exceeds the average bid-ask spread suggests a potential trend reversal.
Illiquid stocks with high P/E ratios relative to their average over the past year tend to underperform.
Low liquidity assets show increased price volatility when market volatility increases.
Extremely large daily price changes are followed by a period of decreased price movement.
Positive earnings surprises accompanied by high trading volume generate stronger price increases.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS * (Volume_post_earnings / Average_Volume_before)

Description: Stocks raising future earnings guidance show higher returns compared to those maintaining or lowering it.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Guidance raised, 0 if unchanged, -1 if lowered

Description: A significant decrease in the P/E ratio in illiquid stocks, despite low volume, may suggest undervaluation and potential price increase.
Expression: Signal = (PreviousPERatio - CurrentPERatio) / PreviousPERatio * (1/Volume); where PreviousPERatio and CurrentPERatio are the P/E ratios of previous and current periods respectively and Volume is the trading volume.

Description: Within a sector, stocks with positive earnings surprises outperform the average sector return.
Expression: Signal = (Stock Return - Sector Average Return) after earnings announcement

Description: Stocks that show a decrease in correlation with the market index while maintaining low volatility will outperform.
Expression: signal = -1 * (correlation(price_t-20:price_t, market_index_t-20:market_index_t) - correlation(price_t-40:price_t-20, market_index_t-40:market_index_t-20)) if stddev(price_t-60:price_t) < threshold else 0

Description: High 10-day rolling volatility predicts higher future 10-day rolling volatility.
Expression: signal = corr(volatility(close_price, window=10), lag_volatility(close_price, window=10, lag=10))

Description: High implied volatility predicts high future implied volatility.
Price volatility after a news event related to an illiquid asset presents a contrarian trading opportunity.
Wide daily high-low ranges predict wider future daily high-low ranges.
Assets exhibiting a sudden increase in volume and a deviation from their average correlation with a benchmark will experience a price movement in the direction of the correlation shift.
Expression: Signal = (Correlation(Asset_i, Benchmark, 1) - Mean(Correlation(Asset_i, Benchmark, 20)) ) * VWAP(Asset_i, 1) / Mean(VWAP(Asset_i), 20)

Description: When the correlation between P/E ratios of two historically correlated assets deviates significantly, the asset with the relatively higher P/E will underperform.
Assets showing a deviation from their normal correlation following news events related to one asset but not the other will revert.
When sector correlation deviates from long-term averages, a mean-reversion trade can be executed by shorting the over-correlated sector and longing the under-correlated sector.
Assets that temporarily exhibit a correlation outside a specified confidence interval around their historical average correlation will revert towards the mean.
Expression: Signal = IF(abs(Correlation(Asset_i, Market, 5) - Mean(Correlation(Asset_i, Market, 60))) > 2 * StdDev(Correlation(Asset_i, Market, 60)), 1, -1)

Description: Temporary divergences in correlation between asset pairs from different markets suggest arbitrage opportunities.
Stocks with high positive beta to CPI surprises outperform in the following month.
Expression: Signal = Beta_CPI * (CPI_actual - CPI_forecast);  Buy if Signal > Threshold

Description: A widening inflation breakeven spread suggests higher future inflation expectations and benefits inflation-linked assets.
Commodities outperform when inflation expectations exceed realized inflation.
When the Producer Price Index (PPI) rises faster than the Consumer Price Index (CPI), value stocks outperform.
Companies with high wage exposure underperform when wage growth exceeds inflation expectations.
High-yield bonds underperform when the yield curve inverts.
Unexpected interest rate hikes negatively impact growth stocks.
Assets with high duration underperform when long-term interest rates rise.
Growth stocks underperform when real interest rates rise unexpectedly.
A price increase confirmed by a simultaneous increase in volume suggests stronger upward momentum.
A significant positive OBV spike suggests accumulating buying pressure.
High volume with minimal price change suggests consolidation before a subsequent significant price movement.
High volume coupled with an unusually low P/E ratio may signal undervaluation and potential price increase.
Several consecutive days with unusually high volume indicate sustained buying or selling pressure.
Stocks with the strongest negative 10-day price momentum will outperform stocks with the strongest positive momentum in the following 2 days.
Expression: Momentum_10d = pct_change(Close, 10); Signal = Rank(Momentum_10d) * -1; Buy stocks with highest Signal.

Description: Stocks whose MACD histogram has recently crossed below zero will outperform stocks whose MACD histogram has crossed above zero over the next 2 days.
Stocks with high P/E ratios that have recently decreased will outperform stocks with low P/E ratios that have recently increased over the following 2 days.
Smaller-cap stocks with low beta that have underperformed the market recently are poised for a relative outperformance.
Expression: Signal = (1 - Beta_t) * (Market_Return - Stock_Return_(t-30:t)) // for smaller-cap stocks only; filter by market cap; use 30-day returns

Description: Smaller cap stocks with low correlation to the market index tend to provide higher risk-adjusted returns.
Stocks with large positive earnings surprises will experience a mean reversion in price within 5 days.
Expression: Signal = -abs( (Close_t - Open_t) / Open_t )  where t is within 5 days post-earnings announcement and Open_t is the opening price on the announcement day.

Description: The impact of an earnings surprise on price decays exponentially over time.
Expression: Signal = (Earnings_Reported - Earnings_Expected) * exp(-k*t), where k is a decay constant and t is time since earnings announcement

Description: Unusually high trading volume after earnings announcements predicts a price reversal within 2 days.
Expression: Signal = (Avg(Volume, 3 days Post-Earnings) / Avg(Volume, 30 days Pre-Earnings)); if Signal > 2 then SELL, else BUY

Description: Unexpectedly high volume signals hidden information and potentially predicts significant price movements.
A change in the correlation of the stock with its sector after the announcement predicts future returns.
Prices revert to their volume-weighted average; higher volume deviations amplify the reversion.
Expression: vwap = sum(price * volume) / sum(volume); signal = (price - vwap) / ATR(20)

Description: High relative strength over 20 days suggests continued upward momentum.
Price breakouts beyond a specified multiple of the Average True Range suggest a strong directional move.
20-day rolling volatility will revert to its 100-day average volatility after deviating significantly.
Expression: volatility20 = stddev(price, 20); avgVolatility100 = MA(stddev(price, 20), 100); signal = (volatility20 - avgVolatility100)/avgVolatility100; if abs(signal) > 0.2 then long if signal < 0, short if signal > 0

Sub_Hypothesis: P/E Ratio Reversion to Sector Mean
Description: A stock's P/E ratio reverts to its sector's average P/E ratio after deviating significantly.
The correlation between two assets reverts to its long-term historical average.
Stocks with a MACD histogram consistently above zero are likely to experience a price decrease.
Expression: signal = MACDHist(Price, 12, 26, 9) where signal > 0.05 for 5 consecutive periods

Description: Assets exceeding their 20-day relative strength moving average with increasing volume signal a likely price increase.
Expression: Signal = IF(RS > MA(RS, 20) AND Volume > MA(Volume, 20), 1, 0)

Description: Stocks with a large price drop on the previous day tend to rebound the next day.
Assets within industries exhibiting strong recent price performance will outperform their peers.
Stocks with P/E ratios significantly below their industry average will experience price appreciation.
Companies with high free cash flow relative to market capitalization will outperform.
Assets that have experienced significant recent price declines will outperform in the long run.
Low-volatility stocks, undervalued based on fundamentals, will generate alpha compared to high-volatility counterparts.
A Hidden Markov Model identifies volatility regimes and predicts transitions.
Negative price returns are followed by increases in implied volatility.
Expression: Signal = ImpliedVolatility(t) - ImpliedVolatility(t-1)  if Return(t-1) < 0; otherwise 0

Description: A higher volatility skew predicts negative future returns.
High trading volume leads to higher realized volatility in the following period.
Negative news sentiment leads to a short-term increase in volatility.
A decrease in asset correlation with a market index predicts an increase in its volatility.
Stocks with high price-to-earnings ratios exhibit higher volatility.
Assets with consistently low trading volume trade at a higher P/E ratio compared to their liquid peers.
Expression: signal = P/E[t] - mean(P/E[t] of liquid peers)

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Simultaneous buying on exchanges with tighter bid-ask spreads and selling on exchanges with wider spreads generates profit from liquidity differences.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Price discrepancies between two highly correlated assets, due to liquidity differences, create arbitrage opportunities.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Price fluctuations in illiquid assets revert to their mean faster than in liquid assets.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Superior access to information in illiquid markets allows for profitable trading based on private information.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Identifying temporary liquidity squeezes in specific assets and exploiting the resulting price dislocations.

Group_Hypothesis: Liquidity : Trading strategies that leverage differences in liquidity across assets or markets
Description: Exploiting differences in market depth (available volume at various price levels) across multiple exchanges.

Group_Hypothesis: Seasonality: Returns exhibit predictable patterns based on the time of year
Description: Small-cap stocks underperform significantly in August.

Group_Hypothesis: Seasonality: Asset prices exhibit predictable patterns related to specific times of the year.
Description: The performance from Halloween to May predicts the performance of the following year.
A sudden spike in social media volume with positive sentiment predicts a price increase within 24 hours.
Stocks with low P/E ratios and high positive sentiment are undervalued and poised for growth.
Expression: Signal = (1/P/E) * SentimentScore ; Buy if Signal > Threshold

Description: High correlation between news and social media sentiment predicts sustained price movements.
Positive news sentiment from 3 days ago predicts a price increase today.
The weighted average of news sentiment, weighted by trading volume, predicts price movement over the next day.
Expression: Signal = SUM(Sentiment_i * Volume_i) / SUM(Volume_i);  if Signal > Threshold then Buy_Signal = 1 else Sell_Signal = -1

Description: Stocks that outperform their sector's average price movement post-earnings display stronger alpha.
Expression: Signal = (Stock Return Post Earnings - Sector Average Return Post Earnings)

Description: The spread between two highly correlated equities will revert to its mean more strongly when sentiment is bearish on the outperforming equity.
Expression: Signal = (Spread - AverageSpread) / StandardDeviationSpread * SentimentScore; where SentimentScore < 0 for bearish

Description: Widening credit spreads in the funding currency predict a negative return for carry trades.
A sudden increase in interest rates will negatively impact both high-yield bonds and related equity sectors, but the correlation will deviate temporarily.
Carry trade positions will unwind when interest rate differentials unexpectedly shrink.
Unexpected supply shocks in related commodities will cause temporary deviations in their price correlation.
Temporary weakening of correlation between assets within the same sector presents arbitrage opportunities.
When a stock's correlation with its sector exceeds a threshold, it tends to revert towards the average sector correlation.
When RSI exceeds 70, a price pullback is expected.
When the price falls below its 10-day moving average by more than 1 standard deviation, a mean reversion trade is triggered.

Sub_Hypothesis: Positive Price Trend and Increasing Volume
Description: Stocks exhibiting a positive price trend accompanied by increasing trading volume tend to continue their upward momentum.
Stocks with the highest 5-day percentage price change will continue to outperform in the short term.

Sub_Hypothesis: Short-Term Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) Positive Crossover
Description: Stocks exhibiting a positive crossover in the short-term MACD signal will continue to increase in price.
Expression: Signal = 1 if MACD(short, long) > signal line; 0 otherwise

Description: Stocks whose price is significantly above their 50-day moving average will maintain their momentum.
Stocks with positive correlation between recent sentiment score and price change will continue to show positive momentum.

Group_Hypothesis: Assets with low valuations (relative to fundamentals) tend to generate higher returns
Description: Stocks with low P/S ratios relative to their sector median will exhibit higher returns over time.
Companies with low debt-to-equity ratios, significantly lower than industry averages, are likely to outperform.
GARCH model's forecast of future volatility predicts future returns.
A widening of the daily price range predicts continued high volatility.
Low-volatility stocks with low correlation to the market index are expected to provide portfolio diversification and enhanced risk-adjusted returns.
Assets experiencing a significant volume spike will underperform the market in the subsequent week.
Assets experiencing sustained high volume coupled with positive price momentum will continue to exhibit positive momentum.
Expression: Signal = Volume(t) * (Price(t) - Price(t-1)); if Signal > Threshold then Buy

Description: Illiquid assets with sudden volume increases will experience a temporary price jump.
High correlation between daily volume and volatility predicts increased future volatility.
High volume in undervalued stocks (low P/E) leads to price appreciation.
Significant order book imbalances in illiquid assets indicate potential price movements.
High volume days followed by a price drop will likely see a price increase in the next day.
When social media sentiment significantly outpaces news sentiment, it predicts increased price volatility.
The predictive power of news sentiment decreases over time, with the most recent sentiment carrying more weight.
Expression: signal = SUM(sentiment_score(t) * exp(-lambda*t) for t in range(1,n))

Description: Stocks with high dividend yields may outperform during certain months.
Expression: Signal =  Correlation(DividendYield, Return) within specific months

Description: Low beta stocks will outperform high beta stocks during a bear market.
High yield bonds that have recently underperformed will outperform in the following week.
Assets with high yields that are currently out of favor (low sentiment) will outperform.
High-volatility assets with high carry will outperform low-volatility assets with low carry.
The difference between short-term and long-term interest rates predicts future returns in long-term bonds.
Expression: Signal = (Long-Term Bond Yield - Short-Term Bond Yield)

Description: High-yield assets with high trading volume will outperform those with low volume.
When the volatility of the price spread between two correlated assets drops below a threshold, a mean reversion is likely.
Expression: signal = 1 if volatility(asset1_price - asset2_price) < threshold else 0

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Exploiting temporary mispricing between correlated assets
Description: Negative news impacting one of two highly correlated assets creates a temporary mispricing opportunity.
Widening spread between implied and realized volatility predicts higher future realized volatility.

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Exploiting temporary mispricing between correlated assets
Description: The price spread between two correlated assets will revert to its 60-day average over a longer time horizon.
Increased selling pressure in December due to tax-loss harvesting leads to lower returns.
Expression: Signal = December Return - Average Return of other months

Description: Trading volume tends to be lower on weekends, leading to price changes upon resumption.
A significant increase in positive sentiment over three days predicts a subsequent price increase.
Expression: IF AVG(SentimentScore[t-2:t]) > 1.5 * STD(SentimentScore[t-30:t]) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High news volume coupled with positive sentiment predicts a stronger price increase than high news volume with neutral or negative sentiment.
Large discrepancies between market sentiment and individual stock sentiment predict price reversion.
A bullish crossover of RSI and a rising sentiment score predicts future price increases.
Expression: Signal = (RSI > 30) AND (SentimentScore_t > SentimentScore_{t-1}); if (Signal) then Buy; else Sell;

Description: A bearish divergence between MACD and sentiment predicts price decline.
Expression: Signal = (MACD[t] is decreasing) AND (SentimentScore[t] is increasing) ? -1 : 0

Description: High negative correlation between volatility and sentiment predicts price stability.
Low P/E ratio combined with strong positive sentiment predicts price appreciation.
A sharp increase in negative sentiment predicts a short-term price increase.
Expression: Signal = -1 * (NegativeSentiment / Time)  if (NegativeSentiment / Time) > Threshold; else Signal = 0

Description: A sudden surge in positive social media mentions predicts a short-term price jump.
Sustained positive news coverage leads to higher prices over the following week.
Higher correlation between daily sentiment change and daily price volatility suggests greater price sensitivity to news.
Extremely high levels of positive sentiment predict a near-term price correction.
Expression: IF (Sentiment_Score[t] > 2 * STDDEV(Sentiment_Score[t-30:t])) THEN SellSignal = 1 ELSE SellSignal = 0

Description: The correlation between lagged sentiment and current price predicts future price movements.
Unexpected positive news significantly impacts price, creating a short-term buying opportunity.
Expression: IF (NewsSentiment[t] > 2 * STDDEV(NewsSentiment[t-30:t])) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: High positive sentiment combined with high trading volume predicts a stronger price increase.
When sentiment is positive but P/E ratio is high, a price correction is likely.
Expression: IF (Sentiment_Score[t] > 0 AND PE_Ratio[t] > 2 * AVG(PE_Ratio[t-12:t])) THEN SellSignal = 1 ELSE SellSignal = 0

Description: High short interest combined with negative sentiment signals a potential short squeeze.
Expression: IF (ShortInterest[t] > Threshold AND Sentiment_Score[t] < -0.5) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: A significant decrease in volume following a period of high volume often precedes a price correction.
Expression: Signal = (Volume[today] < 0.5 * AVG(Volume[last 10 days])) AND (Volume[yesterday] > AVG(Volume[last 10 days]))

Description: Lower lows in price accompanied by higher lows in volume suggests a potential bullish reversal.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Price[t] < Price[t-n] and Volume[t] > Volume[t-n] (where n is a period of prior lows) else 0

Description: Higher highs in price accompanied by lower highs in volume suggests a potential bearish reversal.
Expression: Signal = -1 if Price[t] > Price[t-n] and Volume[t] < Volume[t-n] (where n is a period of prior highs) else 0

Description: A strong positive correlation between volume and price changes suggests a strong trend.
A shift from negative to positive correlation between volume and price indicates a potential trend change.
Expression: signal = 1 if (corr(Volume[t-30:t], Price[t-30:t]) > 0 and corr(Volume[t-60:t-30], Price[t-60:t-30]) < 0) else 0

Description: High volume despite negative sentiment predicts a short-term price increase.
Periods of low volatility in the interest rate differential are followed by periods of higher returns in carry trades.
The spread between two cointegrated stocks will revert to its mean within 5 days.
Expression: Spread = Price(StockA) - Beta * Price(StockB); Signal = (Spread - Mean(Spread, 20)) / StdDev(Spread, 20)

Description: The spread between two cointegrated stocks, adjusted for volatility, will revert to its mean faster during low-volatility periods.
Expression: Spread = Price(StockA) - Beta * Price(StockB); Volatility_Adj_Spread = Spread / Volatility(Spread, 10); Signal = (Volatility_Adj_Spread - Mean(Volatility_Adj_Spread, 20)) / StdDev(Volatility_Adj_Spread, 20)

Description: A temporary decline in correlation between two historically highly correlated stocks will be followed by a mean reversion in correlation.
Expression: Signal = (Correlation(StockA, StockB, 20) - Mean(Correlation(StockA, StockB, 60)) / StdDev(Correlation(StockA, StockB, 60))

Description: Stocks with low 10-day volatility that experience a recent negative price move will see a mean reversion in the following days.
Outperforming sectors will continue to outperform within a specified time horizon.
Negative news sentiment about a stock will lead to a temporary price dip, followed by a mean reversion.
Low P/B stocks outperform high P/B stocks in bull market corrections.
A portfolio of stocks exhibiting mean reversion will have a higher return than a benchmark.
Expression: Portfolio_Return = SUM(w_i * Return_i); Signal = Portfolio_Return - Benchmark_Return

Description: Assets exhibiting high relative strength over the past month tend to continue outperforming their peers in the next week.
Assets that break down from high correlation with their sector tend to underperform.
Assets with relative strength significantly higher than their industry peers outperform.
A short-term relative strength oscillator crossing above its center line suggests positive momentum.
Companies with high return on equity (ROE) and high revenue growth will outperform those with lower ROE and/or lower growth.
Expression: Signal = ROE * RevenueGrowth; Outperform if Signal > Threshold (e.g., 0.2)

Sub_Hypothesis: Low P/E Ratio with High Growth
Description: Stocks with low P/E ratios relative to their industry and high projected earnings growth outperform.
Expression: Signal = (Industry Average P/E) / Stock P/E * Projected Earnings Growth; Buy if Signal > 1.5

Sub_Hypothesis: Strong Sales Growth and Low Debt
Description: Companies with high sales growth and low debt-to-equity ratios will outperform those with lower sales growth or high debt.
Expression: Signal = Sales Growth Rate * (1 - Debt/Equity); Outperformance = 1 if Signal > Threshold, 0 otherwise

Description: Stocks combining high revenue growth with low price volatility will outperform.
Expression: Signal = RevenueGrowth / Volatility (e.g., standard deviation of daily returns); Buy stocks with high Signal

Sub_Hypothesis: Positive Price Momentum and High Growth
Description: Stocks with both positive price momentum and high growth potential will outperform.
Expression: Signal = PriceMomentum * RevenueGrowth; Outperform if Signal > Threshold (e.g., 0.1)

Description: Companies demonstrating increasing market share alongside high revenue growth will outperform.
Expression: Signal = MarketShareGrowth * RevenueGrowth; Outperform if Signal > Threshold (e.g., 0.05)

Description: Stocks with low volatility and high P/E ratios tend to underperform those with high volatility and low P/E ratios.
Stocks with low volatility and high positive correlation to a low-volatility index tend to outperform.
Stocks whose 20-day volatility is decreasing show higher subsequent risk-adjusted returns.
Low volatility stocks experiencing positive earnings surprises generate higher subsequent returns.
Large price gaps up after positive surprises predict continued upward momentum.
Expression: Signal = (Open Price - Close Price (previous day)); Buy if Signal > 0.03 and Earnings Surprise > 0.05

Description: The earnings surprise scaled by trading volume predicts subsequent price momentum.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * Volume / AverageVolume; Alpha = Correlation(Signal, Price_t10 - Price_t0)

Description: The interaction between earnings surprise and the pre-announcement P/E ratio predicts price changes.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * P/E_PreAnnouncement; Alpha = Correlation(Signal, Price_t10 - Price_t0)

Description: The earnings surprise adjusted by the pre-announcement market sentiment predicts future returns.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected) * (1 + Sentiment_PreAnnouncement); Alpha = Correlation(Signal, Price_t20 - Price_t0)

Description: The difference between the actual surprise and the average analyst forecast revision predicts returns.
The post-earnings drift of a stock is influenced by the average earnings surprise within its sector.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS  +  Avg((Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS)<sub>sector</sub>

Description: The interaction between short interest and the earnings surprise predicts short-term price reversal.
Expression: Signal = ShortInterestRatio * (EPS_Reported - EPS_Expected); Alpha = Correlation(Signal, (Price_t0 - Price_t5) / Price_t5)

Description: A significant increase in volume over the past three days predicts a price increase within the next day.
Expression: IF (AVG(Volume, 3) > 2 * AVG(Volume, 30)) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A significant increase in the ratio of volume to price change suggests a potential price reversal.
High volume combined with unusually low price action suggests a potential price bounce.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 1.5 * AVG(Volume[t-20:t]) AND Price[t] < 0.9 * AVG(Price[t-20:t])) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Sub_Hypothesis: Volume Spike followed by Sentiment Shift
Description: A volume spike followed by a positive shift in market sentiment indicates a sustained price increase.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AVG(Volume[t-5:t]) AND Sentiment[t] > Sentiment[t-1] ) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: A volume spike accompanied by a decrease in the correlation between the asset and the market index indicates a potential divergence.
Expression: signal = -1 if volume[t] > avg(volume[t-n:t-1])*k & correlation[t] < correlation[t-1], where k is a multiplier

Description: Assets with unusually high volume followed by unusually low volume tend to revert to their pre-high-volume price within 5 days.
High P/E ratios combined with unusual volume spikes suggest a potential price correction.
Expression: Signal = -1 IF (P/E_t > 2 * Avg(P/E_{t-12:t-1}) AND Volume_t > 2 * Avg(Volume_{t-12:t-1})) ELSE Signal = 0

Description: High short-term volatility combined with a volume spike predicts a price breakout.
Expression: IF (Volatility[t-1:t] > 2 * AVG(Volatility[t-10:t-1]) AND Volume[t] > 2 * AVG(Volume[t-10:t])) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: A large volume spike coupled with negative sentiment creates a contrarian buy opportunity.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 3*AVG(Volume[t-5:t]) AND Sentiment[t] < -1 * AVG(Sentiment[t-10:t])) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: Strong positive sentiment coupled with high trading volume predicts near-term price appreciation.
Stocks with consistently positive news sentiment over the past week outperform the market in the following week.
Expression: signal = SUM(news_sentiment, 7) / 7 //Average daily sentiment over 7 days

Description: Unexpected positive news (deviation from predicted news sentiment) leads to higher returns in the next trading day.
Expression: Signal = (ActualNewsSentiment - PredictedNewsSentiment) / PredictedNewsSentiment; // % deviation from prediction

Sub_Hypothesis: High P/E Ratio and Positive Sentiment
Description: High P/E ratios combined with very positive sentiment create overbought conditions.
A moving average of sentiment scores helps identify overbought and oversold conditions.
Positive news reinforces positive sentiment, leading to amplified price gains.
Negative news diminishes the impact of positive sentiment, reducing price appreciation.
A double bottom pattern followed by a significant increase in volume suggests a bullish price reversal.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (DoubleBottomPatternDetected(Price) == true AND Volume > 1.5 * Avg(Volume, 20)) else 0; //Requires pattern detection function

Description: A breakout above the handle of a cup and handle pattern predicts an increase in price.
A break below the lower trendline of a rising wedge pattern suggests a bearish trend continuation.
Expression: Signal = -1 if Price(t) < LowerTrendline(RisingWedge); Signal = 0 otherwise. (Requires trendline fitting algorithm)

Description: When a stock's price closes below its VWAP for 3 consecutive days, it will subsequently outperform the market.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Close < VWAP for 3 consecutive days) else 0

Description: Companies with low volatility in EPS over the past five years will outperform.
Companies with high insider ownership will outperform.
Companies with CEOs who have served for a long time will outperform.

Sub_Hypothesis: High Revenue Growth with Margin Stability
Description: Companies with high revenue growth and stable profit margins will outperform.
Expression: Revenue Growth[t-1] > 0.1 & ABS(Profit Margin[t-1] - Profit Margin[t-2]) < 0.02

Description: Stocks experiencing upward revisions in earnings estimates outperform those with downward revisions or no change.
Expression: Signal = Number of Upward Earnings Revisions - Number of Downward Earnings Revisions

Description: Stocks experience a dip in price volatility in the 2 days before earnings announcements.
Positive sentiment changes following news events predict short-term upward price movement.
Expression: Signal = (Post-news Sentiment Score - Pre-news Sentiment Score); Buy if Signal > 0.2

Sub_Hypothesis: News Tone and P/E Ratio Interaction
Description: The impact of news sentiment on price is amplified for stocks with high P/E ratios.
Correlation with the market index decreases after a significant earnings announcement.
The magnitude of earnings surprise is directly proportional to the immediate price change.
Expression: Signal = abs(Actual EPS - Expected EPS) * (Price[t] - Price[t-1]) / Price[t-1]

Description: A significant upward revision of earnings estimates after an earnings announcement will lead to higher prices in the following quarter.
Different news categories (e.g., product launch, regulatory change) have different price impact profiles.
Expression: Signal = IF(NewsCategory == 'Product Launch', 1, IF(NewsCategory == 'Regulatory Change', -1, 0)) * (Price[t+1] - Price[t])

Description: Stocks with extreme P/E ratios relative to their historical averages revert towards the mean.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The basis spread between futures and spot prices of a commodity will converge toward zero, indicating arbitrage opportunities.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The basis between a bond and its corresponding futures contract will revert to its historical average.
Expression: signal = bond_price - (futures_price * conversion_factor); if abs(signal - avg(signal, 30)) > threshold then trade accordingly

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price adjustment after a stock split might not perfectly reflect the split ratio, creating a temporary arbitrage window.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The difference between the current market price of a target company and the offer price will converge at the merger completion.
Expression: Signal = OfferPrice - MarketPrice; Trade if Signal > Threshold and TimeToCompletion < 60 days

Description: Higher-yielding currencies with recent positive price momentum will outperform lower-yielding currencies.
Currencies with high interest rates experiencing recent high volatility will likely see a decrease in volatility and subsequent appreciation.
A widening spread between the funding rate of the low-yield currency and the interest rate differential predicts a weakening of the high-yield currency.
Higher trading volume in the high-yield currency relative to the low-yield currency implies stronger price momentum.
Steepening of the yield curve in the high-yield currency market predicts better performance of carry trades.
Stocks that break above their 50-day moving average will outperform in bull markets.
Stocks with high positive correlation to the market index will outperform in bull markets.
During periods of high volatility, defensive sectors tend to outperform growth sectors.
Stocks with low beta (less volatile than the market) will outperform in bear markets.
Stocks that have recently experienced significant price declines will exhibit a short-term reversal in bear markets.
Stocks that experience sharp price drops tend to partially recover in the following days.
Positive correlation with gold prices can signal a flight to safety in bear markets.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(Stock Return, Gold Price Return)

Description: Companies with low debt-to-equity ratios will perform better than highly leveraged companies during bear markets.
A significantly higher trading volume on the earnings announcement day predicts higher returns in the next 2 days.
Expression: Signal = (Announcement Day Volume - Average Volume (past 10 days)) / Average Volume (past 10 days)

Description: The magnitude of the earnings surprise relative to the current P/E ratio predicts subsequent returns.
A positive sentiment shift in news articles after an earnings beat predicts positive price movement in the next two days.
A positive correlation between analyst upgrades and post-earnings price movement indicates a stronger signal.
Companies that beat earnings expectations and show high projected long-term EPS growth outperform the market.
A negative earnings surprise combined with a high debt-to-equity ratio results in a stronger negative price movement.
Upward revisions to future earnings guidance lead to higher returns in the subsequent quarter.
Expression: Signal = (Revised Guidance - Previous Guidance) / Previous Guidance; if Signal > 0 then BUY else SELL

Description: The speed of the market's reaction to an earnings surprise (measured by the time to reach peak price change) is inversely correlated with subsequent returns.
Widening bid-ask spreads in illiquid assets indicate increased transaction costs and potential price reversals.
Expression: Signal = Spread_t / Liquidity_t where Spread is the change in bid-ask spread

Description: Significant overnight price gaps in illiquid assets tend to be partially reversed during the following trading day.
Assets that experience unusually high returns over one day in low-liquidity environments are likely to underperform in the following two days.
Extreme P/E ratios in low-liquidity stocks often indicate mispricing and potential mean reversion.
A sudden drop in liquidity ratios (e.g., trading volume / market cap) is often followed by price corrections.
Stocks with larger positive EPS surprises outperform those with smaller surprises over the next 5 days.
Expression: Signal = (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS

Description: Stocks that experience a positive earnings surprise exhibit a positive drift in price over the five trading days following the announcement.
Higher trading volume following a positive earnings surprise amplifies the positive PEAD effect.
Expression: Signal = (Avg(Volume_t+1:t+5) / Avg(Volume_t-5:t)) * (Actual EPS - Expected EPS) / Expected EPS

Description: Positive news sentiment surrounding an earnings announcement predicts higher short-term stock price returns.
The magnitude of upward revisions in earnings estimates prior to the announcement predicts post-earnings returns.
Positive earnings surprises trigger short covering, leading to rapid price increases.
Periods with high daily high-low range are followed by periods with similarly high ranges.
Low order book depth in high volatility periods indicates potential for further volatility.
When the correlation between two assets within the same sector deviates significantly from the average sector correlation, a price divergence is predicted.
Periods of high market volatility lead to a temporary increase in correlations between assets, followed by a mean reversion.
Correlation between assets varies significantly across different market regimes (bull vs. bear), creating exploitable deviations.
Pairs with high correlation will show negative correlation when one asset experiences a significant decrease in liquidity.
When the correlation between P/E ratio and price deviates significantly from its historical average, a price correction is expected within the next 2 weeks.
The spread between two cointegrated stocks will revert to its long-run equilibrium relationship.
Changes in real interest rates (nominal rates minus inflation) inversely affect stock valuations.
Increased short-term interest rate volatility predicts an upcoming interest rate hike.
Expression: Signal = StandardDeviation(3-Month Treasury Yield, past 30 days)

Description: Stocks with low inflation-adjusted P/E ratios outperform those with high ratios.
High levels of credit default swaps (CDS) spread on corporate bonds signal increased recessionary fears.
A declining unemployment rate generally leads to increased economic activity and stock market gains.
A significant drop in PMI after a period of sustained high values predicts weakening economic conditions.
Expression: Signal = PMI(t) - Average(PMI(t-n)) where n is a period of high PMI

Description: Significant shifts in consumer confidence indicators predict changes in consumer spending and stock market performance.
A significant increase in 5-day average volume followed by a price increase within the next 2 days suggests a bullish trend.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Avg(Volume, 5) > 2 * StdDev(Volume, 20)) and (Price[t+2] > Price[t]) else 0

Description: A significant volume increase after a 10-day declining volume trend indicates a potential price upturn.
Expression: signal = 1 if (volume[t] > 1.2 * volume[t-10] and slope(volume[t-10:t]) > 0) else 0

Description: A significant gap followed by unusually high volume suggests the continuation of the gap direction.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Gap > 0.02*Price) and (Volume > 2*Avg(Volume,20)) else -1 if (Gap < -0.02*Price) and (Volume > 2*Avg(Volume,20)) else 0

Description: Stocks with the highest 10-day momentum but lowest 10-day volatility outperform stocks with the lowest 10-day momentum over the next 3 days.
Stocks with the largest negative sentiment change in the last 24 hours tend to outperform those with the largest positive change over the next day.
Stocks that gapped down by more than 2% yesterday will outperform the market over the next 1 day.
Stocks with the largest price decline from close to next day open tend to outperform on that day.
Inverse ETFs or stocks negatively correlated with the market may provide protection.
Stocks experiencing negative earnings surprises can show a rebound if the magnitude of the negative surprise is less than expectations.
Expression: Signal = -1*abs(EPS_Surprise) / Expected_EPS if EPS_Surprise < 0 && abs(EPS_Surprise) < Expected_EPS*0.2 else 0

Description: Positive sentiment scores in news articles surrounding earnings announcements predict a short-term price increase.
A strong positive correlation between price change and volume after earnings indicates further upward momentum.
Expression: Signal = Correlation(PriceChange, Volume, 5 days Post-Earnings); if Signal > 0.7 then BUY, else SELL

Description: Stocks with upward revisions in earnings estimates outperform in the period following the announcement.
Expression: Signal = Sum(AnalystEstimateRevisions_t) where the sum is over all revisions in the 30 days prior to the announcement

Description: Stocks with higher 3-day relative strength compared to their sector will outperform in the next 2 days.
Stocks with higher 10-day rolling average return will outperform in the following 5 days.
A sustained RSI above 70 indicates continued short-term price momentum.
Expression: signal = 1 if RSI(price, 14) > 70 and RSI(price, 14) > RSI(price, 14)[t-1] else 0

Description: Stocks with higher correlation to the market's 10-day momentum will outperform in the next week.
Stocks with dividend yields substantially above their historical average or industry peers are likely to show price increases.
Stocks trading significantly below their intrinsic value calculated using a discounted cash flow model will outperform.
Stocks hitting their 52-week low will show a positive return within a specified timeframe.
Stocks underperforming their peer group based on a specific metric will outperform in the future.
Undervalued stocks showing positive price momentum will generate higher returns.
Small-cap stocks that exceed earnings expectations by a significant margin will see a price increase.
Expression: Signal = (ActualEPS - ExpectedEPS) / ExpectedEPS; Filter for small-cap stocks only; Higher signal indicates stronger outperformance potential.

Description: Companies with high asset turnover ratios relative to their industry will outperform.
Higher 5-day volatility predicts lower returns in the following week.
A significant increase in 20-day volatility is followed by a temporary price correction.
Assets with high momentum relative to their recent volatility will likely continue their upward trend.
High volume accompanying a surge in volatility indicates stronger momentum and potential for sustained price movement.
Periods of high volatility tend to be followed by further periods of high volatility.
High volatility coupled with negative sentiment presents a potential contrarian long opportunity.
When a stock's volatility diverges from its correlation with a benchmark index, it indicates potential mispricing.
Stocks with high volatility and low P/E ratios present a potential value opportunity.
High volatility coinciding with large order flow suggests institutional activity and potential directional momentum.
Assets experiencing high trading volume with low returns in the past week are likely to underperform in the next week.
A sustained increase in trading volume over the past 3 days suggests upward momentum.
High price volatility in the past week is followed by a period of lower volatility and price stability.
High P/E ratios combined with low trading volume suggest overvaluation.
Expression: Signal = P/E_t / (V_t / AVG(V_{t-N:t})); where P/E_t is price-to-earnings ratio

Description: Assets with low trading volume, relative to their market cap will generate higher returns to compensate for lower liquidity
Increased volatility in news sentiment predicts increased price volatility in the next day.
Positive sentiment exceeding a threshold with low P/E ratio predicts price appreciation.
Expression: IF (sentiment_score > 0.7 AND P/E < 15) THEN signal = 1 ELSE signal = 0

Description: High positive correlation between news sentiment and market index predicts positive price movement.
Strong positive sector-specific sentiment outperforming overall market sentiment predicts outperformance.

Group_Hypothesis: Seasonality: Asset prices exhibit predictable patterns related to specific times of the year.
Description: Negative returns are observed for most assets in the month of August.

Group_Hypothesis: Correlation Arbitrage: Exploiting temporary mispricing between correlated assets
Description: The z-score of the price spread between two assets will revert to zero over time.
The residual from a cointegration regression between two stocks predicts mean reversion of the spread.
Expression: signal = residual from cointegration regression(stockA, stockB)

Description: Recent increases in 5-day price change magnitude predict further short-term price appreciation.
Higher trading volume during the ten days following a positive earnings surprise predicts greater price appreciation.
Stocks with higher 20-day rolling returns outperform in the following 10 days.
Stocks that break above their 10-day correlation with a strong momentum benchmark continue to outperform.
Expression: Signal = IF(Correlation(Stock, Benchmark, t-10:t) > Threshold AND Price(t) > Price(t-1), 1, 0)

Description: When the 7-day moving average crosses above the 21-day moving average, it signals continued upward momentum.
Stocks that experience a sharp decline over 3 days may see a short-term rebound.
Stocks with a significant difference between intrinsic value (calculated using discounted cash flow) and market price will outperform.
Companies with a low price-to-sales ratio and high year-over-year sales growth will outperform the market.
Stocks with high dividend yields and consistent dividend growth over the past five years will outperform.
Companies with low debt-to-equity ratios and high profitability will outperform.
High VIX readings followed by a sharp decrease predict positive market returns over the next week.
A significant increase in SP500 20-day volatility followed by a decline predicts a market rally in the subsequent 10 days.
Expression: signal = -1 * (stddev(SP500_close, 20) - stddev(SP500_close, 20, shifted_by=1)) if stddev(SP500_close, 20) > 2*stddev(SP500_close, 20, shifted_by=1)

Description: Periods of high volatility tend to be followed by periods of lower volatility, creating a mean-reversion signal.
Utilize GARCH modeling to forecast volatility and bet against overestimation of future volatility.
Changes in market skew, particularly a decrease in negative skew, predict positive future returns.
A rising implied volatility put/call ratio predicts lower future returns.
High volatility coupled with negative sentiment predicts lower future returns.
A decreasing ratio of trading volume to volatility may suggest a weakening trend and lower future returns.
Increasing volume with a widening bid-ask spread can indicate decreased liquidity and potential price volatility.
A significant decrease in trading volume after a period of high volume suggests weakening price momentum.
When positive sentiment increases despite falling volume, it suggests a potential price decline.
Low volume with a high P/E ratio suggests a potential risk of price correction.
Expression: Signal = -1 if (Volume[t] < 0.5 * Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND P/E[t] > 1.5 * Avg(P/E[t-12:t-1])) else 0

Description: Assets with high news volume but a low change in volume will see muted price reactions.
A sustained positive trend in news sentiment over three days predicts a price increase on the fourth day.
A 2-day lag in news sentiment predicts price changes on the third day.
High positive sentiment during periods of low volatility predicts sustained price increases.
Expression: Signal = Current Sentiment Score / Current Volatility (e.g., standard deviation of price changes)

Description: A large change in sentiment coupled with high trading volume predicts a significant price movement.
Sentiment from reputable news sources carries more weight in predicting price movements.
Expression: signal = sum(sentiment_score_i * weight_i) , where weight_i is the reputation score of source i

Description: High positive sentiment coupled with a low P/E ratio suggests undervaluation and potential price appreciation.
Market returns show a pattern before and after major political elections.
Expression: Signal = Average return in the month before and after the election

Description: Smaller-cap stocks with low beta exhibiting recent positive momentum outperform.
High-yield stocks that exceed earnings expectations will outperform.
High volatility stocks that have recently underperformed will outperform in the medium term.
Expression: Signal = Volatility Rank (past year) * (Cumulative Return (past 6 months))

Description: Stocks with high positive sentiment scores and high dividend yields will generate higher returns.
High-yield stocks with low correlation to the market will outperform during market downturns.
Expression: Signal = Dividend Yield / Correlation (Stock, Market Index) (past 1 year)

Description: High-yield stocks in sectors with positive growth forecasts will outperform.
Stocks tend to perform better on Mondays and worse on Fridays.
Expression: Signal = Average Return on Mondays - Average Return on Fridays

Description: Increased selling pressure in December due to tax-loss harvesting.
Unexpectedly high news volume related to an asset predicts a short-term price decrease.
Stocks with both strong positive sentiment and upward price momentum will continue to outperform.
Expression: signal = sentiment_score * (price_change / price_lag) ; if (signal > threshold) then long else do nothing

Description: After significant negative news, stocks with low P/E ratios will outperform those with high P/E ratios in the following week.
Expression: Signal = (P/E ratio(t) < Industry Average P/E) * (News Sentiment < 0); Action = Buy if Signal ==1

Description: A significant increase in sentiment volatility predicts increased price volatility and potential trading opportunities.
A sharp drop in the Fear and Greed Index, followed by rising positive sentiment, predicts a price rebound.
High volatility in sentiment scores predicts increased price volatility.
The correlation between lagged news sentiment and future price changes predicts price movement.
A significant deviation between expected and actual news sentiment predicts price movement.
A weighted average of news and social media sentiment predicts price changes.
A drastic drop in volume after a significant price movement suggests exhaustion.
Expression: signal = -1 if (Volume[t] < 0.25 * Volume[t-1] and abs(Price[t]-Price[t-1]) > 0.02*Price[t-1]) else 0

Description: A sudden increase in the positive correlation between volume and price change predicts continued upward momentum.
High trading volume in a high P/E ratio stock indicates a potential correction.
Expression: Signal = -1 if Volume[t] > 2 * avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND P/E[t] > 2 * avg(P/E[t-50:t]) else 0

Description: Decreasing volume despite increasing price momentum indicates a weakening trend.
Expression: Signal = -1 if Momentum[t] > 0 AND Volume[t] < Volume[t-1] AND Volume[t] < avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) else 0

Description: A sudden increase in volume accompanied by rising volatility predicts further price movement.
Expression: Signal = 1 if Volume[t] > 1.5 * avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) AND Volatility[t] > 1.2 * avg(Volatility[t-20:t-1]) else 0

Description: The spread between two similar financial stocks will revert to its historical average.
Two cointegrated stocks with a diverging spread will experience a mean reversion in their spread.
Stocks experiencing a sudden surge in volume will see a price correction in the next 2 days.
Stocks whose post-earnings price movements diverge significantly from their sector's average will see mean reversion within 5 days.
Bull markets favor stocks that have exhibited strong recent price momentum.
Assets experiencing a significant relative volume increase outperform their benchmark in the following week.
Assets exhibiting a relative decrease in volatility outperform their benchmark in the next two weeks.
Stocks that fall significantly tend to revert to their mean during bear market rallies.
Assets that have outperformed their benchmark over the past year tend to continue outperforming in the next quarter.
Assets trading at a significant discount to their intrinsic value (relative to peers) outperform in the long term.
Companies exhibiting accelerating year-over-year EPS growth will outperform companies with decelerating or stagnant EPS growth.
Companies showing both high sales growth and expanding profit margins will significantly outperform peers.
Expression: Signal = SalesGrowth * MarginExpansion; Outperformance = IF(Signal > Threshold, 1, 0)

Sub_Hypothesis: Low Correlation to Market during Growth Spurt
Description: Stocks with low correlation to the overall market during periods of high growth will exhibit higher risk-adjusted returns.
Expression: Signal = 1 - Correlation(StockReturns, MarketReturns) during Growth Period; Outperformance = IF(Signal > Threshold, 1,0)

Sub_Hypothesis: Strong Revenue Growth & High Return on Equity
Description: Companies combining high revenue growth with a superior return on equity (ROE) will outperform.
Expression: Signal = RevenueGrowth * ROE; Outperformance = IF(Signal > Threshold, 1, 0)

Description: Companies demonstrating high revenue growth while maintaining low debt levels will outperform high-debt growth companies.
Expression: Signal = RevenueGrowth / DebtToEquityRatio; Outperformance = IF(Signal > Threshold, 1, 0)

Description: Low volatility stocks with a low Price-to-Earnings ratio are expected to generate higher risk-adjusted returns.
Low volatility stocks that underperform the market during periods of high market volatility tend to rebound.
Low volatility stocks with positive changes in sentiment scores will outperform.
Carry trades benefit when the correlation between the high-yield and low-yield currencies decreases.
Low volatility stocks that exceed earnings expectations tend to exhibit higher returns.
Low volatility stocks with high implied volatility from options markets are expected to see their implied volatility decrease, benefiting the underlying stock.
Low volatility stocks with high dividend yields are expected to provide superior returns.
Larger positive earnings surprises lead to greater short-term price appreciation.
Stocks beating earnings expectations outperform those missing expectations in the following week.
The magnitude of the earnings surprise is positively correlated with subsequent price volatility.
Stocks with unexpectedly high P/E ratios after a positive surprise underperform in the following month.
Expression: signal = -1 * (P/E_t - avg(P/E_t-n)) if EPS_reported > EPS_expected else 0

Description: Positive sentiment scores amplify the positive impact of earnings surprises on price movement.
Positive surprises in a highly correlated sector amplify returns.
Positive surprises coupled with high trading volume predict stronger price increases.
Expression: Signal = IF(EPS_reported > EPS_expected, Volume_t, 0); PriceChange = (Price_t+1 - Price_t) / Price_t

Description: The cumulative effect of positive earnings surprises over the past year is positively correlated with future returns.
Expression: signal = sum((EPS_reported - EPS_expected)_i for i in range(t-252,t))

Description: The magnitude of positive earnings surprise is further enhanced if analyst estimates were recently upgraded.
The magnitude of the price change after a volume spike is proportional to the spike's size.
Expression: Signal = (Volume[t] - Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1])) / Avg(Volume[t-20:t-1]) * (Price[t+5] - Price[t]);  Buy if Signal > 0.

Description: Positive sentiment combined with a volume spike predicts higher future returns.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AvgVolume[t-20]) AND (SentimentScore[t] > 0.5) THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0; Buy if Signal = 1

Description: A large volume spike followed by increased volatility (measured by ATR) predicts price movement.
Stocks with high sector correlation experiencing a volume spike underperform those with low correlation.
Expression: Correlation = Correlation(StockPrice, SectorIndexPrice); IF (Volume[t] > 3 * AvgVolume[t-20]) THEN Signal = -Correlation;

Description: Increased news volume related to a stock, particularly negative news, predicts a short-term price decrease.
Expression: Signal = NewsVolume * (1 - Sentiment); if Signal > Threshold then Sell

Description: Positive sentiment in a sector with low correlation to the market predicts outperformance.
Expression: Signal = Sector_Sentiment * (1 - Market_Correlation) where Sector_Sentiment is the average sentiment in a sector and Market_Correlation is the sector's correlation to the market index.

Description: A sudden surge in trading volume driven by positive sentiment predicts a short-term price increase.
Positive sentiment before earnings announcements predicts positive post-announcement returns.
Expression: Signal = Sentiment(BeforeEarnings) - Sentiment(AfterEarnings); if Signal > Threshold then Buy before announcement

Description: The rate of decay in sentiment after a significant news event predicts future price movements.
Expression: Signal = RateOfDecay(Sentiment, postEvent); if Signal > Threshold then Buy if decay is slow; else sell if fast

Description: A break above the neckline of a double bottom pattern signals a price increase.
Expression: IF (Price[t] > Neckline AND PatternDetected('DoubleBottom')) THEN signal = 1 ELSE signal = 0

Sub_Hypothesis: Volume Spike Ahead of Price Move
Description: A significant volume spike precedes a substantial price change in the same direction.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2*AVG(Volume[t-20:t])) THEN Signal = SIGN(Price[t+1] - Price[t]) ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Breakouts from flag or pennant patterns suggest continuation of the prior trend.
Expression: Identify flag/pennant pattern; Signal = 1 for breakout above/below, 0 otherwise

Description: Three consecutive days of bullish candlesticks with increasing volume predicts further upward movement.
Expression: IF (isBullishCandle(price[t]) AND isBullishCandle(price[t-1]) AND isBullishCandle(price[t-2])) AND (volume[t] > volume[t-1] > volume[t-2]) THEN signal = 1 ELSE signal = 0

Description: Companies with a low price-to-book ratio will outperform.
A significant increase in trading volume immediately following a news event predicts a continuation of the price trend.
Expression: Signal = (Volume_post_news / Volume_pre_news) - 1; // Percentage change in volume

Description: Stocks with a higher correlation to positive sector news outperform those with lower correlation.
Stocks receiving multiple analyst upgrades after an earnings announcement will outperform the market in the next month.
Expression: Signal = Number of Upgrades - Number of Downgrades; if Signal > 1 then BUY else if Signal < -1 then SELL else HOLD

Description: A lower P/E ratio after earnings announcement signals better future performance.
Higher frequency of positive news articles around earnings release correlates with better returns.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price difference between a cross-listed stock on two different exchanges will revert to its historical mean within a week.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price difference between an ETF and its underlying assets will revert to its average tracking error within two days.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The basis (difference between futures and spot prices) of a commodity will converge to zero as the contract expiration approaches.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The difference in equivalent yields between similar bonds will revert to zero within one trading day.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: Inconsistencies in exchange rates across three currencies will create profit opportunities within minutes.

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The price of a stock plus a put option should equal the price of a call option plus the present value of the strike price (Put-Call Parity).
Expression: Signal = StockPrice + PutPrice - CallPrice - StrikePrice * exp(-r*T); Trade if |Signal| > Threshold

Group_Hypothesis: Arbitrage: Exploiting pricing discrepancies between related assets
Description: The basis between an index and its futures contract will revert to its historical mean before expiry.
Carry trades involving highly liquid currencies will show reduced slippage and better returns.
The basis between the spot and forward exchange rates will revert to its historical mean.
Central bank interventions to suppress the high-yield currency reduce future returns of the carry trade.
Carry trade returns are sensitive to unexpected macroeconomic news releases.
Stocks with high recent price momentum will continue to outperform in a bull market.
Expression: Signal = 10-day average price change / 20-day average price change

Description: High volume on price dips indicates stronger accumulation and future price appreciation in smaller-cap stocks.
Stocks with decreasing debt-to-equity ratios will outperform.
Low-volatility stocks will outperform in bear markets.
Companies with low debt-to-asset ratios are more resilient during bear markets.
Stocks positively correlated with gold price will outperform in a bear market.
Stocks with high cash reserves and low leverage will outperform.
Stocks exceeding earnings expectations by more than 5% will exhibit positive price momentum for the next 5 trading days.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) > 1.05 THEN Signal = 1 ELSE Signal = 0;  Momentum = AVG(Price[t+1:t+5]) - Price[t]

Description: Stocks with negative earnings surprises will see a significant increase in trading volume on the announcement day, predicting further price decline.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) < 0.95 THEN Signal = Volume[t] / AVG(Volume[t-20:t-1]) ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Stocks exceeding earnings expectations will see a temporary expansion of their P/E ratio in the days following the announcement.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) > 1.02 THEN Signal = AVG(P/E[t+1:t+3]) / P/E[t] ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Stocks experiencing a negative earnings surprise will see short covering and a price rebound within 3 days if short interest is high.
Expression: signal = 1 if (epsActual < epsEstimate) and (shortInterest > threshold) else 0

Description: Positive earnings surprises will lead to a significant improvement in news sentiment scores within 2 days of the announcement.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) > 1.05 THEN Signal = AVG(SentimentScore[t+1:t+2]) - SentimentScore[t] ELSE Signal = 0

Description: The correlation between a stock's price and its sector's price will increase significantly after a large earnings surprise (positive or negative).
A large positive earnings surprise will lead to upward revisions of future EPS estimates by analysts.
Expression: IF (EPS_Actual / EPS_Estimate) > 1.1 THEN Signal = AVG(RevisedEPS_Estimate) - EPS_Estimate ELSE Signal = 0

Sub_Hypothesis: Magnitude of Surprise and Price Change
Description: The magnitude of the earnings surprise is directly proportional to the percentage price change in the next 3 days.
Expression: Signal = (EPS_Actual - EPS_Estimate) / EPS_Estimate; PriceChange = (Price[t+3] - Price[t]) / Price[t]

Description: A significant volatility spike after a surprising earnings announcement will be followed by a period of lower volatility.
Expression: IF (Volatility[t] > 2 * AVG(Volatility[t-20:t-1])) THEN Signal = AVG(Volatility[t+1:t+5]) / Volatility[t] ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Stocks with persistently low trading volume that show positive price momentum over the past month will continue to outperform the market in the next week.
Expression: Signal = (Avg(Volume_30d) < Median(Volume_30d, Market)) && (Price_t / Price_t-30 > 1.1); if Signal then Buy

Description: Negative news sentiment will lead to temporary price depression.
Periods of high volatility in low-liquidity assets tend to cluster, offering opportunities to exploit mean reversion within those clusters.
Expression: Signal = StdDev(Price[-5:-1]) / Avg(StdDev(Price) over past 30 days)

Description: Positive guidance revisions after a positive earnings surprise amplify the price effect.
Expression: Signal = (Post-earnings Guidance - Pre-earnings Guidance) / Pre-earnings Guidance; if Signal > 0.1 then Position = Long; else Position = 0

Description: Low volatility stocks experiencing a sudden increase in trading volume will show positive returns.
Expression: signal = volume_t / avg(volume_t-20:t-1) if stddev(price_t-20:price_t) < threshold else 0

Description: Stocks with a high number of analyst upgrades before the earnings announcement outperform.
Expression: Signal = Number of Analyst Upgrades in the last month

Description: Positive revisions of future earnings estimates by analysts after the announcement predict higher stock prices.
Expression: Signal = Sum of changes in future EPS estimates post-announcement

Description: High 20-day rolling volatility predicts higher future 20-day rolling volatility.
A GARCH(1,1) model forecasts future volatility based on past volatility and squared returns.
Periods with consistently high trading volume predict higher future volatility.
Increased volatility in news sentiment scores precedes increased market volatility.
Detection of jumps in price series predicts higher subsequent volatility.

Sub_Hypothesis: Mean Reversion of Pair Trade Correlation
Description: Pairs of stocks with historically high correlation that show a recent drop in correlation will revert towards their historical average correlation.
Pairs of stocks with historically high correlation but currently exhibiting low volume-weighted correlation will show increased price divergence in the following 2 days.
When the correlation between high P/E ratio stocks and the market weakens, these stocks are expected to underperform the market.
A sudden increase in correlation between low-volatility stocks and the market indicates a potential short-term market downturn.
Unexpected news impacting one asset, despite a strong historical correlation with another, predicts a temporary decorrelation.
Pairs of stocks with historically low correlation that exhibit unusually high correlation recently are expected to mean revert.
Low correlation between implied volatility of a stock and its corresponding options indicates a potential mispricing opportunity in the options market.
A widening differential between nominal and inflation-adjusted bond yields signals future inflation.
Significant changes in the inflation breakeven rate (difference between nominal and inflation-protected bond yields) predict changes in inflation expectations.
Cyclical stocks outperform when PMI shows positive momentum.
Unexpectedly high GDP growth leads to upward pressure on equity prices.
Inversion of the yield curve (short-term yields exceeding long-term yields) predicts an increased probability of a recession.
A significant decrease in the unemployment rate predicts increased economic activity.
A three-day average volume exceeding 2 standard deviations above the 20-day average volume predicts a price increase within the next 5 days.
Expression: IF (AVG(Volume[t-2:t]) > 2 * STDEV(Volume[t-19:t])) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: High volume on days with unusually low prices signals a future price increase.
Expression: Signal = 1 IF (Volume_t > 1.5*Avg(Volume_{t-20:t-1}) AND Price_t < 0.95 * Avg(Price_{t-20:t-1})) ELSE Signal = 0

Description: Divergence between the closing price and the volume-weighted average price after a volume spike suggests a price correction.
Expression: Signal = -1 * Abs(VWAP_t - Price_t) IF Volume_t > 2 * Avg(Volume_{t-10:t-1}) ELSE Signal = 0

Description: A sharp decrease in volume following a significant volume spike signals a potential price consolidation or reversal.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] < 0.5 * Volume[t-1] AND Volume[t-1] > 2 * AVG(Volume[t-19:t-1])) THEN SellSignal = 1 ELSE SellSignal = 0

Description: High volume coupled with a low P/E ratio suggests a potential buying opportunity.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > 2 * AVG(Volume[t-19:t]) AND P/E[t] < IndustryAverageP/E) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: An increasing rate of volume over the past 7 days suggests a potential price trend strengthening.
Expression: IF (Volume[t] > Volume[t-1] AND Volume[t-1] > Volume[t-2] AND Volume[t-2] > Volume[t-3] AND Volume[t-3] > Volume[t-4] AND Volume[t-4] > Volume[t-5] AND Volume[t-5] > Volume[t-6] AND Volume[t-6] > Volume[t-7]) THEN BuySignal = 1 ELSE BuySignal = 0

Description: Stocks currently below their 20-day moving average and above their 50-day moving average will outperform stocks above their 20-day moving average and below their 50-day moving average over the next 2 days.
Expression: Signal = IF(Price < 20Day_MA AND Price > 50Day_MA, 1, IF(Price > 20Day_MA AND Price < 50Day_MA, -1, 0))

Description: Stocks that gapped down significantly the previous day outperform stocks that gapped up significantly over the next day.
Stocks with high projected revenue growth rates over the next 3 years will outperform.
Stocks with a low Price-to-Earnings-to-Growth (PEG) ratio will outperform.
Stocks with consistently increasing earnings surprises over the past four quarters will outperform.
Small-cap companies with low debt-to-equity ratios outperform those with higher leverage.
Expression: Signal = 1 / DebtToEquityRatio; Filter for small-cap stocks only; Higher signal indicates stronger outperformance potential.

Description: Companies with a consistently high return on equity (ROE) will outperform.
Stocks with significant insider buying activity will outperform.
A combination of high trading volume and positive news sentiment before earnings predicts positive post-earnings returns.
Smaller cap stocks with unusually low P/E ratios tend to see positive price corrections.
Expression: Signal = 1 / P/E[t] if P/E[t] < percentile(P/E[t-60:t],20) else 0

Description: A significant change in P/E ratio after earnings announcement predicts subsequent price movements in the same direction.
A decrease in correlation between a stock and the market index before earnings predicts higher post-earnings returns.
Stocks with improving sentiment scores (e.g., news sentiment) over the past week will exhibit positive returns.
Expression: Signal = Sentiment_Score[t] - Sentiment_Score[t-5]; if Signal > 0.2 then Buy; else Sell

Description: Assets breaking above a recent resistance level will exhibit upward momentum.
Assets where the short-term moving average crosses above the long-term moving average will continue to outperform.
Stocks experiencing a Bollinger Band squeeze followed by a breakout will generate high returns.
Expression: Signal = 1 if (Upper_Band[t] - Lower_Band[t]) < Threshold and Price[t] > Upper_Band[t] else 0; if Signal == 1 then Buy

Description: Stocks that deviate significantly from their 200-day moving average will likely exhibit a reversion towards this average within the next 3 months.
Stocks with a significant difference between intrinsic value (calculated via DCF) and market price will outperform.
Companies with high revenue growth rates and low P/E ratios will generate superior returns.
